OC 1093 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î³ÏÎµÏ…Ï„á½°Î½ á¼ˆÏ€á½¹Î»Î»Ï‰ | ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½á½µÏ„Î±Î½| ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Ï‰ Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¾¶Ï‚ á¼€ÏÏ‰Î³á½°Ï‚ | Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½, â€œI desireâ€: where, in such an invocationï¼ˆá¼°á½¼Î–Îµá¿¦,po/rois, k.t.l.ï¼‰, ste/rgw surely cannot mean, â€œI am content.â€ Oed. asks: â€œDoes this supplication mean that some new dread has seized you ï¼ˆÎ´Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ï¼‰? Or that ye have set your hearts ï¼ˆÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ï¼‰ on some particular boon which I can grant?â€â€”Others render ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ â€œhaving acquiesced.â€ This admits of two views. ï¼ˆiï¼‰ â€œAre ye afraid of suffering? Or have ye already learned to bear suffering?â€ To this point the glosses á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¼Îµá½·Î½Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, Ï€Î±Î¸á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚. But this seems unmeaning. He knows that the suffering has come, and he does not suppose that they are resigned to it ï¼ˆcp. v. 58ï¼‰. ï¼ˆiiï¼‰ Prof. Kennedy connects á¼¢ ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á½¡Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ | á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ±ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î½ Ï€á¾¶Î½; i.e. are ye come in vague terror, or in contentment, as believing that I would be willing to help you? This is ingenious and attractive. But (a) it appears hardly consonant with the kingly courtesy of this opening speech for Oedipus to assume that their belief in his good-will would reconcile them to their present miseries. (b) We seem to require some direct and express intimation of the king's willingness to help, such as the words á½¡Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚Ï€á¾¶Î½ give only when referred to Ï†Ïá½±Î¶Îµ. (c) The rhythm seems to favour the question at ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚. â€”ÏƒÏ„á½³Î¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, explained as â€œhaving endured,â€ may be rejected, because ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ the sense is against itâ€”see on ï¼ˆiï¼‰ above: ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ in classical Greek = â€œto be proof against,â€ not â€œto sufferâ€: ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰ ÏƒÏ„á½³Î¾Ï‰, á¼”ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ¾Î± are unknown to Attic, which has only the pres. and the imperf. á½¡Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ ï¼ˆto be connected with Ï†Ïá½±Î¶Îµï¼‰ implies the apodosis of a conditional sentence. Grammatically, this might be either ï¼ˆaï¼‰ Îµá¼° Î´Ï…Î½Î±á½·Î¼Î·Î½, Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹ á¼„Î½, or (b) Îµá¼° á¼ Î´Ï…Î½á½±Î¼Î·Î½, á¼¤Î¸ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½ á¼„Î½: here, the sense fixes it to (a). á½¡Ï‚, thus added to the gen. absol., expresses the supposition on which the agent acts. Xen. Mem. 2.6.32 á½¡Ï‚ Î¿á½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¿á½·ÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆá¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ï¼‰ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Ï‡Îµá¿–ÏÎ±Ï‚,Î´á½·Î´Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÂ· â€œas ï¼ˆyou may be sureï¼‰ I will not lay hands on you, teach me.â€

á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ±ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î½ Ï€á¾¶Î½Â· Î´Ï…Ïƒá½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼‚Î½

ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰Î½ Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰, not Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„Îµá½·ÏÏ‰, is the spelling attested by Attic inscriptions of circ. 550-350 B.C.: see Meisterhans, Grammatik der Attischen Inschriften, p. 89. Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰Î½. An infinitive or participle, which for any reason would regularly take Î¼á½µ, usually takes Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ if the principal verb of the sentence is negative. Here, Î´Ï…Ïƒá½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ = Î¿á½Îº Îµá½á½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚: Dem. 19.123 ï¼ˆÏ€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ï¼‰ Ï‡Î±Î»ÎµÏ€Î±á½¶ Î»Î±Î²Îµá¿–Î½Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Î¿ÏÎºá½·á¾³ï¼ˆsc. Î»Î±Î¼Î²á½±Î½Î¿Î½Ï„Î¹,ï¼‰ where Ï‡Î±Î»ÎµÏ€Î±á½· = Î¿á½ á¿¥á¾´Î´Î¹Î±Î¹Â· â€œcities not easy to take, unless by a protracted siege.â€ The participial clause, Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰Î½, is equivalent to a protasis, Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î¹. Prof. Kennedy holds that the protasis is Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹ understood, and that Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰Î½ is epexegetic of it: â€”â€œYesï¼ˆÎ³á½±Ïï¼‰ I should be unfeeling, if I did not wish ï¼ˆto help youï¼‰: that is, if I refused to pity such a supplication as this.â€ But the double negative Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ could not be explained by a negative in the protasis ï¼ˆÎµá¼° Î¼á½´ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹ï¼‰Â· it implies a negative in the apodosis ï¼ˆÎ´Ï…Ïƒá½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼´Î·Î½ï¼‰. Since, then, the resolution into Î¿á½Îº Îµá½á½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼´Î·Î½ is necessary, nothing seems to be gained by supposing a suppressed protasis, Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹.

Î²Ï‰Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ The altars of the Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½· in front of the palace, including that of Apollo Î›á½»ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆ919ï¼‰. Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½°Î½ Ï€Ï„á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. So Andromache to her child â€”Î½ÎµÎ¿ÏƒÏƒá½¸Ï‚ á½¡ÏƒÎµá½¶ Ï€Ï„á½³ÏÏ…Î³Î±Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ€á½·Ï„Î½Ï‰Î½ á¼Î¼á½±Ï‚ Eur. Tro. 746. The proper Attic form for the aor. of Ï€á½³Ï„Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ was á¼Ï€Ï„á½¹Î¼Î·Î½, which alone was used in prose and Comedy. Though forms from á¼Ï€Ï„á½±Î¼Î·Î½ sometimes occur in Tragedy, as in the Homeric poems, Elms. had no cause to wish for Ï€Ï„á½±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ here.

á½¡Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½bouleuma/twn I take these two verses with the whole context from v. 35, and not merely as a comment on the immediately preceding words Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á¼¶ÏƒÎ¸á½± Ï€Î¿Ï…. Oedipus has had practical experienceï¼ˆá¼Î¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïá½·Î±ï¼‰ of great troubles; when the Sphinx came, his wisdom stood the trial. Men who have become thus á¼”Î¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î¹ are apt to be also ï¼ˆÎºÎ±á½·ï¼‰ prudent in regard to the future. Past facts enlighten the counsels which they offer on things still uncertain; and we observe that the issues of their counsels are not usually futile or dead, but effectual. Well may we believe, then, that he who saved us from the Sphinx can tell us how to escape from the plague. Note these points. ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ The words á¼Î¼Ï€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ and Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ serve to suggest the antithesis between past and future. ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½°Ï‚tw=n bouleuma/twn= literally, the occurrences connected with ï¼ˆresulting fromï¼‰ the counsels. The phrase, â€œissues of counsels,â€ concisely expresses this. The objection which has been made to this version, that Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½± is not Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½µ, rests on a grammatical fallacy, viz., that, in Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½° Î²Î¿Ï…Î»Îµá½»Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, the genitive must be of the same kind as in Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½´ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»Îµá½»Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Ï„á½»Ï‡Î· is not Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½µ, yet in Soph. OC 1506 it stands with a gen. of connection, just as Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½± does here:ï¼ˆÎ¸Îµá¿¶Î½ï¼‰ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î·Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½´Î½ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼”Î¸Î·ÎºÎµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á½Î´Î¿á¿¦ ï¼ˆa good fortune connected with this comingï¼‰. Cp. Thuc. 1.140 á¼Î½Î´á½³Ï‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½°Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼¦ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½ á¼€Î¼Î±Î¸á¿¶Ï‚ Ï‡Ï‰Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ á¼¢ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±Î½Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¿Ï…: the issues of human affairs can be as incomprehensible in their course as the thoughts of man ï¼ˆwhere, again, the â€œoccurrences connected with human affairsâ€ would be more literalï¼‰: ib. Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½°Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î±Ï‚ Ï„ÏÎµÏ€Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚, altering their views according to the events. Thuc. 3.87 Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚ Ï„á¿· á¼€Ï€Î¿Î²á½±Î½Ï„Î¹, by the issue which has resulted. ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰

45 Î¶á½½ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á½Ïá¿¶ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 45

Line 47

Îµá½Î»Î±Î²á½µÎ¸Î·Î¸â€™ have a care for thy reputeâ€” as the next clause explains. Oed. is supposed to be above personal risk; it is only the degree of his future glory ï¼ˆ55ï¼‰ which is in question; a fine touch, in view of the destined sequel.

Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ Ï„Îµ Îºá¼€Î¼á½² ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒâ€™ The king's soul grieves for the whole State, â€”for himself, charged with the care of it, â€”and for each several manï¼ˆÏƒá½³ï¼‰. Line 153

Ï€á½±Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ transitive, governing Ï†Ïá½³Î½Î±, making my heart to shake; not intransitive, for Ï€Î±Î»Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, with Ï†Ïá½³Î½Î± as accus. of the part affected. á¼”Î½Î¹ = á¼”Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹, is available.

Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Î³Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ not, a weapon consisting in a device, but a weapon discovered by human wit, á¼”Î³Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ á¾§ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Î»á½³Î¾ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ being a bold equivalent for Î¼Î·Ï‡Î±Î½á½´ á¼€Î»ÎµÎ¾Î·Ï„Î·Ïá½·Î±.

á¾§ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Î»á½³Î¾ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î³á½°Ï á¼”ÎºÎ³Î¿Î½Î± ğŸ—©
Line 171

This future has the support of the best MSS. in Xen. Anab. 7.7.3 Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„Ïá½³ÏˆÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½á½¡Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»ÎµÎ¼á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼€Î»ÎµÎ¾á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ¸Î±: and of grammarians, Bekk. ÎºÎ»Ï…Ï„á¾¶Ï‚ Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½”Î¾ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï„á½¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 172

Ï„á½¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ by births. Women are released from travail, not by the birth of living children, but either by death before delivery, or by still births. See on 26, and cp. Hes. WD 244 Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½·ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½. If Ï„á½¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½= â€œin child-bedâ€ ï¼ˆand so the schol., á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„á½¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ï¼‰, the meaning would be simply, â€œwomen die in child-bed,â€ â€”not necessarily â€œbefore child-birthâ€; but the point here is the blight on the fruits of earth and womb, â€”not merely the mortality among women.

á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î½ Î´â€™á¼„Î»Î»á¿³ â€œone after another.â€ The dative here seems to depend mainly on the notion of adding implied by the iteration itself; though it is probable that the neighbourhood of Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‚ in Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½·Î´Î¿Î¹Ï‚ may have been felt as softening the boldness. Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ Î³á½°Ïá¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Reading Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½, as Herm. suggested, instead of Ï„á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹, I construe thus: â€”Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹ Î½á½»Î¾ á¼€Ï†á¿‡, á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï á¼Ï€á½³ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿, â€œIf night omit anything ï¼ˆin the work of destructionï¼‰, day comes after it to accomplish this.â€ Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ is the infin. expressing purpose, as often after a verb of going or sending, where the fut. participle might have been used: cp. Hdt. 7.208 á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¼Ï€ÎµÎºÎ±Ï„á½±ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿Î½ á¼±Ï€Ï€á½³Î±, á¼°Î´á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹[ = á½€Ïˆá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½] á½Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï„á½³ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹, Îº.Ï„.Î».Â· Thuc. 6.50 Î´á½³ÎºÎ± Î´á½² Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î½Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿á½”Ï€ÎµÎ¼ÏˆÎ±Î½ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½³Î³Î±Î½ Î»Î¹Î¼á½³Î½Î± Ï€Î»Îµá¿¦ÏƒÎ±á½· Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºá½³ÏˆÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ·Ïá¿¦Î¾Î±Î¹. Here the pres. inf. is right, because the act is not single but repeated. Observe how strongly Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ is supported by the position of the word ï¼ˆâ€œTo accomplish, â€”if night omit aught, â€”day followsâ€ï¼‰. No version of Ï„á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹ explains this. The most tolerable is: â€”â€œIn fulnessâ€” if night omit aughtâ€”day attacksï¼ˆá¼Ï€á½³ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ï¼‰ thisâ€: but I do not think that such a rendering can stand. See Appendix.

Îµá¼°á¼€Ï†á¿‡ Cp. 874 Îµá¼° á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÏ€Î»Î·ÏƒÎ¸á¿‡ ï¼ˆlyricï¼‰: Soph. OC 1443 Îµá¼° ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ·Î¸á¿¶ ï¼ˆdialogueï¼‰: Soph. Ant. 710 ÎºÎµá¼´ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¾– ï¼ˆdo.ï¼‰. In using Îµá¼° with subjunct., the Attic poets were influenced by the epic usage, on which see Monro, Homeric Grammar sect. 292. The instances in classical prose are usu. doubtful, but in Thuc. 6.21 Îµá¼° Î¾Ï…ÏƒÏ„á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½ has good authority.

Ï„á½¹Î½, á½¦ Ï„á¾¶Î½ Ï€Ï…ÏÏ†á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 199

á¼Ï€â€™á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ for the adverbial á¼Ï€á½· separated from á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, cp. Soph. OC 1777 Î¼Î·Î´â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€Î»Îµá½·Ï‰ | Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Î½ á¼Î³Îµá½·ÏÎµÏ„Îµ. This is â€œtmesisâ€ in the larger sense: tmesis proper is when the prep. is essential to the sense of the verb: Hom. Il. 8.108 Î¿á½”Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€â€™ Î‘á¼°Î½Îµá½·Î±Î½ á¼‘Î»á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ = Î¿á½“Ï‚ á¼€Ï†ÎµÎ¹Î»á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ Î‘á¼°Î½Îµá½·Î±Î½: cp. Monro H. G. sect. 176.

I read á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ | Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦, the change of Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ and Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ having necessarily followed that of á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ into á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»á½¼Î½ due to an interpretation which took the latter with Ï†Î¿Î²Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹. Cp. Thuc. 4.83 ï¼ˆArrhibaeus, the enemy of Perdiccas, makes overtures to Brasidas, and the Chalcidians exhort Brasidas to listenï¼‰: á¼Î´á½·Î´Î±ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½´ á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„á¿· Î ÎµÏÎ´á½·ÎºÎºá¾³ Ï„á½° Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½±, â€œthey impressed upon him that he must not remove the dangers from the path of Perdiccasâ€â€” by repulsing the rival power of Arrhibaeus. á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„á½° Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½±= to take them away (á¼Îº) from under ï¼ˆá½‘Ï€á½¹ï¼‰ the feet, â€”from the path immediately before him: Ï„á¿· Î ÎµÏÎ´á½·ÎºÎºá¾³ being a dat. commodi. Similarly Hdt. 7.8 Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾Î±ÏÎ±Î¹ÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½, â€œwhen these have been taken out of the way.â€ So here: ÎºÎµá¼° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¿Î²Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹, and if he is afraid ï¼ˆas knowing himself to be the culpritï¼‰, then I bid him ï¼ˆÎºÎµÎ»Îµá½»Ï‰ continued from 226ï¼‰ á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„á½¸ á¼Ï€á½·ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î± to take the peril of the charge out of his path, Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ï¼ˆÏƒÎ·Î¼Î±á½·Î½Î¿Î½Ï„Î±ï¼‰ by speaking against himself. If the culprit is denounced by another person, he will be liable to the extreme penalty. If he denounces himself, he will merely be banished. By denouncing himself, he forestalls the danger of being denounced by another. For other explanations, see Appendix.

Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦Â· Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î³á½°Ï á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ Î¼á½²Î½

á¼€Î²Î»Î±Î²á½µÏ‚ the reading of A and most MSS., â€œwithout damage,â€ á¼€Î¶á½µÎ¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚, is far more suitable than á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á½µÏ‚ to this context: and Soph. has the word as a cretic in Soph. Although in L á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á½µÏ‚ appears as the older reading, so common a word was very likely to be intruded; while it would be difficult to explain how the comparatively rare á¼€Î²Î»Î±Î²á½µÏ‚ could have supplanted it. A metrical doubt may have first brought á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á½µÏ‚ in. Dindorf, reading á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á½µÏ‚, recognises the superior fitness of á¼€Î²Î»Î±Î²á½µÏ‚ here, and thinks that it may be the true reading, even though its appearance in the margin of L was due to conjecture.

á¼Ï€Îµá½»Ï‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ imprecate on myself: Plat. Criti. 120b Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± á¼Ï€ÎµÏ…Î¾á½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á¼•ÎºÎ±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á¿· á¼€Ï†â€™ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹. Îµá¼°Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ The imperfect indic. of a verb denoting obligationï¼ˆá¼”Î´ÎµÎ¹, Ï‡Ïá¿†Î½, Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá¿†ÎºÎµÎ½, Îµá¼°Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ï¼‰, when joined without á¼„Î½ to an infinitive, often implies a conditional sentence with imperfect indic. in protasis and apodosis: e.g. Î¿á½Îº Îµá¼°Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ á¼á¾¶Î½ = Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼°á¾¶Ï„Îµ ï¼ˆÎµá¼° Ï„á½° Î´á½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î± á¼Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–Ï„Îµï¼‰, you would not ï¼ˆnowï¼‰ be neglecting it ï¼ˆif you did your dutyï¼‰: Xen. ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î±á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½° á¼¦Î½ á¼‚Î½ á¼ÎºÏ€ÎµÏ†Ï…Îºá½¹Ï„Î± common things of ï¼ˆ = ties consisting inï¼‰ kindred children would have been generated: = ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î±á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½´ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ á¼Î³á½³Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿ á¼„Î½, a brood, common to Laius and Oedipus, of children akin to each other ï¼ˆas having the same mother, Iocastaï¼‰ would have issued: â€œchildren born of one mother would have made ties between him and me.â€ For á¼„Î½ doubled cp. 139, 339. ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¿¶Î½ = á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á¿¶Î½, á½Î¼Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½ï¼ˆSoph. Ant. 1 á½¦ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½±Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†Î¿Î½ á¼¸ÏƒÎ¼á½µÎ½Î·Ï‚ Îºá½±ÏÎ±ï¼‰. The language of this passage is carefully framed so as to bear a second meaning, of which the speaker is unconscious, but which the spectators can feel: Iocasta has actually borne children to her own son Oedipus: thus in ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î±á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½°á¼ÎºÏ€ÎµÏ†Ï…Îºá½¹Ï„Î±, the obvious sense of ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½±, â€œcommon to Laius and Oedipus,â€ has behind it a second sense, in which it hints at a brood who are brothers and sisters of their own sire: see below 1403 f. This subtle emphasisâ€”so ghastly, Î¾Ï…Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½â€” of the iteration in ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½± must not be obliterated by amending ÎºÎ¿á½·Î½â€™ á¼„Î½ into Îºá½»Î¼Î±Ï„â€™ ï¼ˆNauckï¼‰ or ÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ¼Î±Ï„â€™ ï¼ˆBlaydesï¼‰. Î¿á½Îº á¼Î½ á¼€ÏÎ³Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³Î»Î¹Ï€Î¿Î½ would have meant, â€œI did not leave this among things neglected.â€ Soph. fuses the negative form with the positive, and instead of ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³Î»Î¹Ï€Î¿Î½ writes á¼Ï€ÏÎ±Î¾á½±Î¼Î·Î½: â€œI saw to this ï¼ˆmidd.ï¼‰ in such a manner that it also should not be among things neglected.â€ Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ï¼ˆmidd.ï¼‰ elsewhere usu. = â€œto exactâ€ ï¼ˆThuc. 4.65 etc.ï¼‰: here = Î´Î¹Î±Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, effect for oneself. Line 312

á¿¥á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹ ÏƒÎµÎ±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». á¿¥á½»ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±á½· Ï„Î¹ is to draw a thing to oneself, and so to protect it. á¿¥á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î¼á½·Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î± here = literally, â€œtake the defilement under thy careâ€; i.e. â€œmake it thy care to remove the defilement.â€ Cp. Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ„Î·Ï„â€™ á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ±á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î·Ï‚ ï¼ˆSoph. Aj. 803ï¼‰, shelter my hard fate, ï¼ˆinstead of, â€œshelter me from it.â€ï¼‰

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„ÎµÎ¸Î½Î·Îºá½¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚ gen. of the source from which the Î¼á½·Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î± springs, â€”more pathetic than Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…, as reminding the hearer that vengeance is due for innocent blood. á¼€Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá½»Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ not brought to an end: Hom. Il. 4.175 á¼€Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½µÏ„á¿³ á¼Ï€á½¶ á¼”ÏÎ³á¿³. Plut. Mor. 114f Ï„á½¸ Î³á½°Ï Î´á½´ á¼€Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá½»Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ Î½Î¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½¸ Ï€á½³Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Î·Ï‚. Here, a man â€œwith whom one cannot make an end,â€ â€”who cannot be brought to the desired issue. In freely rendering, â€œWilt thou never make an end?â€ we remember, of course, that the adj. could not literally mean â€œnot finishing.â€ Possibly it is borrowed from the colloquial vocabulary of the day: the tone is like that of the Latin odiosus.

á¼Î¾ÎµÎºá½·Î½Î·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎºÎ¹Î½Îµá¿–Î½ is used of starting game, Soph. El. 567 á¼Î¾ÎµÎºá½·Î½Î·ÏƒÎµÎ½ Ï€Î¿Î´Î¿á¿–Î½ |á¼”Î»Î±Ï†Î¿Î½: of rousing one from rest, Soph. á½‘Ï†Îµá½¶Ï‚ having secretly sent as his agent, â€œhaving suborned.â€ Plat. The passage shows how Asiatic superstitions had already spread among the vulgar, and were scorned by the educated, in Greece. á½ Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ Îµá¼°Î´á½¼Ï‚ = á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ á¾”Î´Î·, â€œI, a man who knew nothing,â€ the generic Î¼á½µ, here with concessive force, â€”â€œthough I knew nothing, I silenced herâ€ ï¼ˆqui nihil scirem, vici tamenï¼‰. á¼€Î³Î·Î»Î±Ï„Îµá¿–Î½ = Ï„á½¸ á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î»Î±á½»Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ï¼ˆsee on 98ï¼‰, in this case á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎ·Î»Î±Ï„Îµá¿–Î½ ï¼ˆ100ï¼‰, to expel the Î¼Î¹á½±ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Ï. Hdt. 5.72 ÎšÎ»ÎµÎ¿Î¼á½³Î½Î·Ï‚á¼€Î³Î·Î»Î±Ï„á½³ÎµÎ¹ á¼‘Ï€Ï„Î±Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î± á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î± ï¼ˆhouseholdsï¼‰ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Ï‰Î½. The smooth breathing is supported by Hesychius, by the grammarians in Bekker's Anecd. 1.328.32, and by most MSS. of Soph.; while the aspirate is given by L here, by Eustathius ï¼ˆ1704, 5ï¼‰, and by Suidas, who quotes this verse. Curtius distinguishes ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ á¼€Î³â€, á¼„Î³â€Î¿Ï‚, guilt, object of awe, whence á¼Î½Î±Î³á½µÏ‚: Skt. ag-as, vexation, offence: Etym. sect. 116: ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ root á¼…Î³, á¼…Î¶â€Î¿â€Î¼Î±Î¹ reverence, á¼…Î³â€Î¹Î¿â€Ï‚ holy, á¼Î³â€Î½á½¹â€Ï‚ pure: Skt. jageï¼ˆjaegea_-miï¼‰, reverence, consecrate: Etym. sect. 118. In Aesch. Lib. 154 and Soph. Ant. 775 he would with Herm. write á¼…Î³Î¿Ï‚ as = â€œconsecrated offering.â€ In both places, however, á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ï¼ˆ= piaculumï¼‰ satisfies the sense ï¼ˆsee n. on Soph. Ant. 775ï¼‰; and for á¼…Î³Î¿Ï‚ there is no other evidence. But this, at least, seems clear: the compound synonym for Ï„á½¸ á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î»Î±á½»Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ï¼ˆThuc. 1.126ï¼‰ should be written á¼€Î³Î·Î»Î±Ï„Îµá¿–Î½. Î´á½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ is the scornful phrase of an angry man; I know little concerning thee, but from thine aspect I should judge thee to be old: cp. 562 where Oed. asks, Ï„á½¹Ï„â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ á½ Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½á¿ƒ; Not ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ â€œseemed,â€ as opposed to really being; nor ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ â€œwast felt by meâ€ to be old: a sense which the word surely could not yield.

á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Î´á½² Îº.Ï„.Î». Verses 422-425 correspond with the actual process of the drama. á¼… Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¾Î¹Ïƒá½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹ which shall make thee level with thy ï¼ˆtrueï¼‰ self, â€”by showing thee to be the son of Laius, not of Polybus; â€”and level with thine own children, i.e. like them, the child of Iocasta, and thus at once á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ï„á½µÏ ï¼ˆ458ï¼‰. Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á½Î¼á½¸Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± ğŸ—©

Ï„Î¿á½Î¼á½¸Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± i.e., it is Apollo who speaks by my mouth, which is not, as thou deemest, the á½‘Ï€á½¹Î²Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± ï¼ˆSoph. OC 794ï¼‰ of Creon.

Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€Î·Î»á½±ÎºÎ¹Î¶Îµ acc. to Aristot. Top. 6.6 Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€Î·Î»Î±ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÎ¼á½¹Ï‚ was defined as á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° Ï‡Î»ÎµÏ…Î±Ïƒá½·Î±Ï‚, insult expressed by scoffing: so in Aristot. Nic. á½¡Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–. ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ must be accented; else the contrast would be, not partly between ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ and Î³Î¿Î½Îµá¿¦ÏƒÎ¹, but solely between Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿– and some other verbal notion. Line 451

Ï„á½¸Î½ Î›Î±á¿“ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ cp. 267.

Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ a foreign sojourner: Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚, because Oed. was reputed a Corinthian. In poetry Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ is simply one who comes to dwell with others: it has not the full technical sense which belonged to it at Athens, a resident alien: hence the addition of Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ was necessary. Cp. Soph. OC 934 Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î³á¿†Ï‚: Soph. Ant. 868 Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½“Ï‚ ï¼ˆto the deadï¼‰ á¼…Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½¼ Î¼á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼”ÏÏ‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹.

Îµá¼¶Ï„Î± Î´á½² opp. to Î½á¿¦Î½ Î¼á½³Î½, implied in á¼Î½Î¸á½±Î´Îµ. â€”á¼Î³Î³ÎµÎ½á½´Ï‚, â€œnative,â€ as Î³ÎµÎ½Î½Î·Ï„á½¹Ï‚ is opp. to Ï€Î¿Î¹Î·Ï„á½¹Ï‚ (adoptivus).

Î³ÎµÎ½á½³Ï„Î±Ï‚, one concerned with Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚, either passively, = â€œson,â€ as here ï¼ˆcp. Î³Î·Î³ÎµÎ½á½³Ï„á¾³ Eur. Phoen. 128ï¼‰, or actively, = â€œfather.â€ Eur. has both senses. Cp. á¼€Î½Î±Ï€Î»á½±ÎºÎ·Ï„Î¿Î¹ not erring or failing in pursuit: cp. Soph. á¼”Î»Î±Î¼ÏˆÎµ see on 186.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î½Î¹Ï†á½¹ÎµÎ½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ the message flashed forth like a beacon from that snow-crowned range which the Thebans see to the west. I have elsewhere noted some features of the view from the Dryoscephalae pass over Mount Cithaeron:â€”â€œAt a turn of the road the whole plain of Boeotia bursts upon the sight, stretched out far below us. There to the north-west soars up Helicon, and beyond it, Parnassus; and though this is the middle of May, their higher cliffs are still crowned with dazzling snow. Just opposite, nearly due north, is Thebes, on a low eminence with a range of hills behind it, and the waters of Lake Copais to the north-west, gleaming in the afternoon sun.â€ ï¼ˆModern Greece, p. 75.ï¼‰

Ï†á½±Î¼Î± Î Î±ÏÎ½Î±ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î´Î·Î»Î¿Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼°Ï‡Î½Îµá½»ÎµÎ¹Î½.

Join Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î´Î·Î»Î¿Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ±, and take Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± as neut. plur., â€œby all means.â€ The adverbial Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± is very freq. in Soph., esp. with adj., as Soph. Trach. 338 Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Î³á½°Ï Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ¼Î·Î½ á¼Î³á½½: Here, the emphasis on Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± would partly warrant us in taking it as acc. sing. masc., subject to á¼°Ï‡Î½Îµá½»ÎµÎ¹Î½. á½•Î»Î±Î½ á¼€Î½á½± Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½Ï„ÏÎ± ÎºÎ±á½¶
Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼°Ïƒá½¹Ï„Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚

Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼°Ïƒá½¹Ï„Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚ is J. F. Martin's and E. L. Lushington's brilliant emendation of Ï€ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±á¿–Î¿Ï‚ á½ Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚, the reading of the first hand in L. It is at once closer to the letters, and more poetical, than Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼…Ï„Îµ Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆDorville, â€”where the use of á¼…Ï„Îµ is un-Atticï¼‰, Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÎ± Ï„Î±á½»ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ ï¼ˆM. Schmidtï¼‰, or Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚ á½¡Ï‚ Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚, which last looks like a prosaic correction. I suppose the corruption to have arisen thus. A transcriber who had before him Î Î•Î¤Î¡Î‘Î£Î™Î£ÎŸÎ¤Î‘Î¥Î¡ÎŸÎ£ took the first O for the art., and then amended Î Î•Î¤Î¡Î‘Î£Î™Î£ into the familiar word Î Î•Î¤Î¡Î‘Î™ÎŸÎ£. With a cursive MS. this would have been still easier, since in Ï€ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï„Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚ the first Ï‚ might have been taken for Î¿ ï¼ˆnot a rare mistakeï¼‰, and then a simple transposition of Î¹ and the supposed Î¿ would have given Ï€ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±Î¹Î¿Ï‚. It is true that such compounds with á¼°ÏƒÎ¿ usu. mean, not merely â€œlike,â€ but â€œas good asâ€ or â€œno better thanâ€: e.g. á¼°ÏƒÎ¿Î´Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½, á¼°Ïƒá½¹Î¸ÎµÎ¿Ï‚, á¼°Ïƒá½¹Î½ÎµÎºÏ…Ï‚, á¼°Ïƒá½¹Î½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, á¼°Ïƒá½¹Ï€Î±Î¹Ï‚, á¼°Ïƒá½¹Ï€ÏÎµÏƒÎ²Ï…Ï‚. Here, however, á¼°Ïƒá½¹Ï„Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚ can well mean â€œwildâ€ or â€œfierce of heartâ€ as a bull. And we know that in the lost ÎšÏá½³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± Soph. used á¼°ÏƒÎ¿Î¸á½±Î½Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ in a way which seemed too bold to Pollux ï¼ˆ6. 174 Î¿á½ Ï€á½±Î½Ï… á¼€Î½ÎµÎºÏ„á½¹Î½ï¼‰, â€”probably in the sense of â€œdread as deathâ€ ï¼ˆcp. Soph. Aj. 215 Î¸Î±Î½á½±Ï„á¿³ Î³á½°Ï á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï€á½±Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á¼ÎºÏ€Îµá½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹ï¼‰. The bull is the type of a savage wanderer who avoids his fellows. Soph. in a lost play spoke of a bull â€œthat shuns the herd,â€ Bekk. Anecd. 459.31 á¼€Ï„Î¹Î¼Î±Î³á½³Î»Î·Ï‚Â· á½ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î·Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼€Î³á½³Î»Î·Ï‚ Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚Â· Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚. Verg. Georg. 3.225 ï¼ˆtaurusï¼‰ Victus abit, longeque ignotis exulat oris. Theocr. 14.43 Î±á¼¶Î½á½¹Ï‚ Î¸Î·Î½ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÏ„Î±á½· Ï„Î¹Ï‚, á¼”Î²Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½â€™ á½•Î»Î±Î½: a proverb á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¼á½´ á¼€Î½Î±ÏƒÏ„ÏÎµÏ†á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ï¼ˆschol.ï¼‰. Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï€Î¿Ï„á¾¶Ï„Î±Î¹ the doom pronounced by Apollo hovers around the murderer as the Î¿á¼·ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï‚ around some tormented animal: he cannot shake off its pursuit. The haunting thoughts of guilt are objectively imaged as terrible words ever sounding in the wanderer's ears.

á¼€Ï„Î»Î·Ï„á¿¶Î½ The verb á¼€Ï„Î»Î·Ï„á½³Ï‰, found only here, implies an active sense of á¼„Ï„Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚, impatiens: as Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„á½¹Ï‚, pass. in Soph. OC 1036, is active in Soph. Trach. 446. Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Î½ The charge does not hurt him in a single aspect only,â€”i.e. merely in his relation to his family and friends ï¼ˆá¼°Î´á½·á¾³ï¼‰. á¼€Î»Î»á½°Î¼á½²Î½ Î´á½´ cp. Soph. Trach. 627.

á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÏ„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼‚Î½, â€œmight perhaps have come.â€ á¼§Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼‚Î½ is a potential indicative, denoting for past time what á¼”Î»Î¸Î¿Î¹ á¼‚Î½ denotes for future time. That is, as á¼”Î»Î¸Î¿Î¹ á¼‚Î½ can mean, â€œit might come,â€ so á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼‚Î½ can mean, â€œit might have come.â€ á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼‚Î½ does not necessarily imply that the suggested possibility is contrary to fact; i.e., it does not necessarily imply, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½. Cp. Dem. 37.57 Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ á½ Î¼á½´ Ï€Î±Ïá½¼Î½á¼Î³á½½ Ï„á½· ÏƒÎµ á¼ Î´á½·ÎºÎ·ÏƒÎ±; â€œhow was I likely to do you any wrong?â€ [This was the view taken in my first edition. Goodwin, in the new ed. of his Moods and Tenses ï¼ˆ1889ï¼‰, has illustrated the â€œpotentialâ€ indicative with á¼„Î½ ï¼ˆsect. 244ï¼‰, and has also shown at length that á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼‚Î½ does not necessarily imply the unreality of the supposition ï¼ˆsect. 412ï¼‰. This answers the objection which led me, in a second edition, to suggest that Ï„Î±Ï‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ was here no more than Ï„á½±Ï‡Î±, and that the usage arose from an ellipse ï¼ˆá¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ, Ï„á½±Ï‡Î± Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼”Î»Î¸Î¿Î¹ï¼‰. In Soph. OC 964 ff. also I should now take á¼¦Î½Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ as = â€œperchance it may have been.â€]

Î¿á½Îº Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™ Creon has asked: â€œDid any trace of madness show itself in the bearing or in the speech of Oedipus?â€ The Chorus reply: â€œOur part is only to hear, not to criticise.â€ These nobles of Thebes ï¼ˆ1223ï¼‰ have no eyes for indiscretion in their sovereign master.

Line 532

The Chorus have described the unknown murderer as they imagine himâ€”a fugitive in remote places. They now touch on the charge laid against Oedipus, â€”but only to say that it lacks all evidence. Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½–Î½. Î¿á½–Î½ marks the turning to a new topic, with something of concessive force: â€œ it is true that the murderer is said to be hereâ€: Î¼á½²Î½ is answered by Î´á½² after Î»á½³Î¾Ï‰. Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½° is adverbial: for ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ Ï„Î±Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹ could not mean ÎºÎ¹Î½Îµá¿–, stirs up, raises, dread questions: ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±, á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†á½±ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± are acc. sing. masc., referring to Î¼Îµ understood. The schol., Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½° Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ á¼„Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±, has favoured the attempt to take the participles as acc. neut. plur., á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†á½±ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± being explained as â€œnegativeâ€ in the sense of â€œadmitting of negation,â€ á¼€Ï€á½¹Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½·Î±Î½ Î´ÎµÏ‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î± ï¼ˆTricliniusï¼‰. This is fruitless torture of language. Nor will the conj. á¼€Ï€Î±Ïá½³ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„â€™ ï¼ˆBlaydesï¼‰ serve: for, even if the Chorus found the charge credible, they would not find it pleasing. Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± is not â€œbelieving,â€ but â€œapproving.â€ Cp. Soph. Ant. 1102 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼Ï€Î±Î¹Î½Îµá¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎµÎ¹ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½; â€œand you recommend this course, and approve of yielding?â€ The pregnant force of Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± is here brought out by the direct contrast with á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†á½±ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±. In gauging the rarer uses of particular words by an artist in language so subtle and so bold as Soph. we must never neglect the context.

Soph. cannot have written these two verses as they stand; and the fault is doubtless in 1280. Line 532

His memory recalls the scene as if he were again approaching it on his way from Delphi. First, he descries three roads converging in a deep glen or ravine ï¼ˆÏ„ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚ Îºá½³Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸Î¿Î¹â€”ÎºÎµÎºÏÏ…Î¼Î¼á½³Î½Î· Î½á½±Ï€Î·ï¼‰:then, descending, he comes to a coppice ï¼ˆÎ´ÏÏ…Î¼á½¹Ï‚ï¼‰at a point where his own road narrows ï¼ˆÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ½Ï‰Ï€á½¹Ï‚ï¼‰just before its junction with the two others ï¼ˆá¼Î½ Ï„ÏÎ¹Ï€Î»Î±á¿–Ï‚ á½Î´Î¿á¿–Ï‚ï¼‰.See on 733. The genuineness of v. 1399 has been groundlessly questioned, on the score of supposed tautology. The language may be compared with that of the verses from the Oedipus of Aeschylus ï¼ˆfr. 167ï¼‰, quoted in the Introduction.

á¼¢ Ï„Î¿á½”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». Î³Î½Ï‰ÏÎ¹Î¿á¿–Î¼Î¹ â€œFutures in â€á¼°ÏƒÏ‰ are not common in the good Attic period: but we have no trustworthy collections on this pointâ€: Curtius, Verb 11.312, Eng. tr. 481. Î¿á¼¶ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½¡Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î·ÏƒÎ¿Î½; In more than twelve places of the tragic or comic poets we have this or a like form where a person is eagerly bespeaking attention to a command or request. á¼¢ Î¿á½Îº Aesch. Seven 100 á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»ÎµÏ„â€™ á¼¢ Î¿á½Îº á¼€ÎºÎ¿á½»ÎµÏ„â€™ á¼€ÏƒÏ€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏ„á½»Ï€Î¿Î½; Hom. Od. 4.682 á¼¢ Îµá¼°Ï€á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î±Î¹ Î´Î¼Ï‰á¿‡ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÏƒá¿†Î¿Ï‚ Î¸Îµá½·Î¿Î¹Î¿. Line 594

Î¿á½”Ï€Ï‰ ironical: see on 105.

Ï„á½° Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Îºá½³ÏÎ´ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±Î»á½±: honours which bring substantial advantage ï¼ˆreal power and personal comfortï¼‰, as opp. to honours in which outward splendour is joined to heavier care. Soph. El. 61 Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶ Î¼á½³Î½, Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¿¥á¿†Î¼Î± Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Îºá½³ÏÎ´ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½: i.e. the sound matters not, if there is Îºá½³ÏÎ´Î¿Ï‚, solid good.

Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Ï‡Î±á½·ÏÏ‰ â€œall men wish me joyâ€: lit. â€œI rejoice with the consent of all menâ€: all are content that I should rejoice. Cp. Soph. Birds 445 Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Î½Î¹Îºá¾¶Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÏÎ¹Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ | ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ±Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹. The phrase has been suggested by Ï‡Î±á¿–Ïá½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹, but refers to the meaning rather than to the form of the greeting: i.e. Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Ï‡Î±á½·ÏÏ‰ is not to be regarded as if it meant literally, â€œI have the word Ï‡Î±á¿–ÏÎµ said to me by all.â€ This is one of the boldly subtle phrases in which the art of Soph. recalls that of Vergil. Others understand: ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ â€œI rejoice in all,â€ â€”instead of suspecting some, as the Ï„á½»ÏÎ±Î½Î½Î¿Ï‚ does, who Ï†Î¸Î¿Î½á½³ÎµÎ¹Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ á¼€Ïá½·ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹xai/rei de\ toi=si kaki/stoisi tw=n a)stw=n Hdt. 3.80: ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ â€œI rejoice in relation to allâ€â€” i.e. am on good terms with all: ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰ â€œI rejoice in the sight of allâ€: i.e. enjoy a happiness which is the greater because men see it: ï¼ˆ4ï¼‰ â€œI rejoice in all things.â€ This last is impossible. Of the others, ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ is best, but not in accord with the supposed position of Oedipus á½ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Ï‚.

á¼ÎºÎºÎ±Î»Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Those who have a boon to ask of Oed. come to the palace ï¼ˆor to Creon's own house, see on 637ï¼‰ and send in a message, praying Creon to speak with them. Ï„á½¸Ï„Ï…Ï‡Îµá¿–Î½ sc. á½§Î½ Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½. Line 600

Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿ Îº.Ï„.Î». Creon has been arguing that he has no motive for treason. He now states a general maxim, â€œNo mind would ever turn to treason, while it was sound.â€ As a logical inference, this holds good only of those who are in Creon's fortunate case. If, on the other hand, ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î½ means â€œalive to its own highest good,â€ and not merely to such self-interest as that of which Creon has spoken, then the statement has no strict connection with what precedes: it becomes a new argument of a different order, which might be illustrated from Plato's ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼‘Îºá½¼Î½ Î¿á½Î´Îµá½·Ï‚. It would be forcing the words to render: â€œA base mind could not approve itself wise,â€ i.e. â€œsuch treason as you ascribe to me would be silly.â€

ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Î½ Î´á½² the sterling worth of the upright man is not fully appreciated until it has been long tried: but a knave is likely ï¼ˆby some slipï¼‰ to afford an early glimpse of his real character. Îµá¼°Îºá½±Î¸Ï‰ the aor. subj. is certainly most suitable here: Soph. Phil. 761 Î²Î¿á½»Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î»á½±Î²Ï‰Î¼Î±Î¹; Soph. El. 80 Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ | Î¼Îµá½·Î½Ï‰Î¼ÎµÎ½; In such phrases the pres. subj. ï¼ˆimplying a continued or repeated actï¼‰ is naturally much rarer: Î²Î¿á½»Î»ÎµÎ¹ á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€á¿¶Î¼ÎµÎ½ Xen. Mem. 3.5.1. As regards the form of Îµá¼°Îºá½±Î¸Ï‰, Curtius ï¼ˆVerb 11. 345, Eng. tr. 505ï¼‰, discussing presents in â€Î¸Ï‰ and past tenses in â€Î¸Î¿Î½ from vowel stems, warns us against â€œlooking for anything particularly aoristic in the Î¸â€ of these verbs. In Greek usage, he holds, â€œa decidedly aoristic forceâ€ for such forms as ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¸Îµá¿–Î½ and Îµá¼°ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½â€œ never established itselfâ€: and he justly cites Soph. El. 1014 as a place where Îµá¼°ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ is in no way aoristic. He would therefore keep the traditional accent, and write ÏƒÏ‡á½³Î¸ÎµÎ¹Î½, Îµá¼°Îºá½±Î¸ÎµÎ¹Î½, with Buttmann. Now, while believing with Curtius that these forms were prob. in origin presents, I also think that in the usage of the classical age they were often aorists: as e.g. ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¸Îµá¿–Î½ in Aesch. Seven 429 distinctly is.

ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³Î½á½¸Ï‚Ï€ÎµÏá½±Ïƒá¿ƒÏ‚ â€œthou art seen to be sullen when thou yieldest, but fierce when thou hast gone far in wrathâ€: i.e., as thou art fierce in passion, so art thou sullen in yielding. Line 678

Creon leaves the scene. The Chorus wish Iocasta to withdraw Oedipus also, that he may be soothed in the house: but she wishes first to learn how the dispute began.

Line 681

Î´á½¹ÎºÎ·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ a suspicion resting on mere assertions ï¼ˆthose made by Oedipusï¼‰, and not supported by facts ï¼ˆá¼”ÏÎ³Î±ï¼‰: hence á¼€Î³Î½á½¼Ï‚, unknowing, guided by no real knowledge. Line 687

The evasive answer of the Chorus has nettled Oedipus by implying that the blame was divided, and that both parties ought to be glad to forget it. He could never forget it ï¼ˆ672ï¼‰.

á½Ïá¾·Ï‚ á¼µÎ½â€™ á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ conveys indignant reproach: a grave charge has been laid against your king; instead of meeting it with denial, you are led, by your sympathy with Creon, to imply that it cannot be directly met, and must be hushed up. Line 708

Î¼á½±Î¸â€™ Îº.Ï„.Î».: learn that thou canst find no mortal creature sharing in the art of divination.

ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ ethic dat.: á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½ = á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ ï¼ˆEur. Supp. 427 Ï„á½· Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½;ï¼‰: Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î·Ï‚. partitive gen. The gods have prescience ï¼ˆ498ï¼‰; but they impart it to no man, â€”not even to such ministers as the Delphian priests. Iocasta reveres the gods ï¼ˆ647ï¼‰: it is to them, and first to Apollo, that she turns in trouble ï¼ˆ911ï¼‰. But the shock which had befallen her own life, â€”when at the bidding of Delphi her first-born was sacrificed without saving her husband Laiusâ€”has left a deep and bitter conviction that no mortal, be he priest or seer, shares the divine foreknowledge. In the Greek view the Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‚ might be ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ first, the god himself, speaking through a divinely frenzied being in whom the human reason was temporarily superseded ï¼ˆhence the popular derivation of Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá½µ from Î¼Î±Î½á½·Î±ï¼‰: Plat. Tim. 71e Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá½´Î½ á¼€Ï†ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½»Î½á¿ƒ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î¸ÏÏ‰Ï€á½·Î½á¿ƒ Î´á½³Î´Ï‰ÎºÎµÎ½Â· Î¿á½Î´Îµá½¶Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼”Î½Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½±Ï€Ï„ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá¿†Ï‚ á¼Î½Î¸á½³Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î»Î·Î¸Î¿á¿¦Ï‚: this was much the same as the Egyptian belief, Hdt. 2.83 Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá½´ Î´á½² Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ á½¦Î´Îµ Î´Î¹Î±Îºá½³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Ï‰Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¶ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºá½³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ á¼¡ Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î·, Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´á½² Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„ÎµÎ¾ÎµÏ„á½³ÏÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹. ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ Secondly, the Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‚ might be a man who reads signs from birds, fire, etc., by rule of mystic science: it was against this Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î· that scepticism most readily turned: Eur. El. 399 Î›Î¿Î¾á½·Î¿Ï… Î³á½°Ï á¼”Î¼Ï€ÎµÎ´Î¿Î¹ | Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÎ¼Î¿á½·, Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´á½² Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá½´Î½ Ï‡Î±á½·ÏÎµÎ¹Î½ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰. Iocasta means: â€œI will not say that the message came through the lips of a truly god-possessed interpreter; but at any rate it came from the priests; it was an effort of human Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá½µ.â€ So in 946, 953 Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá½»Î¼Î±Ï„Î± are oracles which professed to come from the gods. Others render: â€” â€œNothing in mortal affairs is connected with the mantic artâ€: i.e. is affected by it, comes within its ken. Then á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½ will not stand for á¼”Ï‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ ï¼ˆwhich it could not doï¼‰, but for á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹, as meaning â€œis of,â€ â€œbelongs to.â€ Hdt. has á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ as = Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ with expressions equivalent to an adverb, as Hdt. 2.91 á¼€Î³á¿¶Î½Î± Î³Ï…Î¼Î½Î¹Îºá½¸Î½ Î´Î¹á½° Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ á¼€Î³Ï‰Î½á½·Î·Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±, â€œconsisting in every sort of contest,â€ as he might have said Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±: so Hdt. 3.128 Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï€ÏÎ·Î³Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ ï¼ˆ= Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î±Ï‡á¿¶Ï‚ï¼‰: Hdt. 6.42 ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï‡á½½ÏÎ·Î½ ï¼ˆ= á¼Î¼Ï€á½³Î´Ï‰Ï‚ï¼‰ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚Â· Hdt. 7.220 á¼Î½ á¼”Ï€ÎµÏƒÎ¹á¼‘Î¾Î±Î¼á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±. Line 733

ÏƒÏ‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½´ Î´â€™ á½Î´á½¹Ï‚ In going from Thebes to Delphi, the traveller passes by these â€œBranching Roads,â€ â€”still known as the Ï„Ïá½·Î¿Î´Î¿Î¹, but better as the ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ½á½¹: from Daulia it is a leisurely ride of about an hour and a half along the side of Parnassus. The following is from my notes taken on the spot: â€” â€œA bare isolated hillock of grey stone stands at the point where our path from Daulia meets the road to Delphi, and a third road that stretches to the south. There, in front, we are looking up the road down which Oedipus came [from Delphi]; we are moving in the steps of the man whom he met and slew; the road runs up a wild and frowning pass between Parnassus on the right hand and on the left the spurs of the Helicon range, which here approach it. Away to the south a wild and lonely valley opens, running up among the waste places of Helicon, a vista of naked cliffs or slopes clothed with scanty herbage, a scene of inexpressible grandeur and desolationâ€ ï¼ˆModern Greece p. 79ï¼‰. At this ÏƒÏ‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½´ á½Î´á½¹Ï‚ Pausanias saw Ï„á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î›Î±á¿“Î¿Ï… Î¼Î½á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¿á¼°Îºá½³Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼‘Ï€Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…: the legend was that Damasistratus king of Thebes had found the bodies and buried them ï¼ˆ10. 5 sect. 4ï¼‰. The spot has a modern monument which appeals with scarcely less force to the imagination of a visitor, â€”the tomb of a redoubtable brigand who was killed in the neighbourhood many years ago.

I do not believe that Soph., or any Greek, could have written Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½ | Ï„á½·Î½â€™ Îµá¼¶Ï‡Îµ, Ï†Ïá½±Î¶Îµ, Ï„á½·Î½Î± Î´â€™ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½´Î½ á¼¥Î²Î·Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½, which Herm. was inclined to defend as if Ï„á½·Î½Î± Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Îµá¼¶Ï‡Îµ = Ï„á½·Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½. Line 758

The poet has neglected clearness on a minor point. The Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµá½»Ï‚â€” sole survivor of the four attendantsâ€”had fled back to Thebes with the news that Laius had been slain by robbers ï¼ˆ118-123ï¼‰. This news came before the trouble with the Sphinx began: 126-131. And the play supposes an interval of at least several days between the death of Laius and the election of Oedipus: see on 736. Hence ÎºÎµá¿–Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶Îµá¼¶Î´Îµ cannot mean that the Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµá½»Ï‚, on reaching Thebes, found Oedipus already reigning. Nor can we suggest that he may have fled from the scene of the slaughter before he was sure that Laius had been killed: that is excluded by 123 and 737. Therefore we must understand:â€” â€œwhen he had come thence, and [afterwards] found that not only was Laius dead, but you were his successor.â€ ï¼ˆFor the parataxis Ïƒá½³ Ï„ÎµÎ›á½±ÏŠá½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ see on 673.ï¼‰ I incline to suspect, however, that Sophocles was here thinking of the man as coming back to find Oedipus already on the throne, and had overlooked the inconsistency. The conjecture Î›Î±á¿“Î¿Ï… Ï„Îµ Î´á½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î± for Î›á½±ÏŠá½¹Î½ Ï„â€™ á½€Î»Ï‰Î»á½¹Ï„Î± ï¼ˆWolffï¼‰ would remove the difficulty, but seems very improbable.

Line 775

The epithet â€œDorianâ€ carries honour: Meropee was of the ancient stock, claiming descent from Dorus son of Hellen, who settled in the region between Oeta and Parnassus. The Scholiast's comment, Î ÎµÎ»Î¿Ï€Î¿Î½Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î±Îºá½µ, forgets that the Theban story is laid in times before the Dorian conquest.

á¼€ÏƒÏ„á¿¶Î½ Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–, Ï€Ïá½·Î½ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î· ğŸ—©
Line 776

Ï€Ïá½·Î½ Î¼Î¿Î¹á¼Ï€á½³ÏƒÏ„Î· ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ Ï€Ïá½·Î½ with infin. = our â€œbefore,â€ whether the sentence is affirmative or negative: á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ ÎºÎ»Î·Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹, Î¿á½Îº á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ ÎºÎ»Î·Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹. ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ Ï€Ïá½·Î½ with a finite mood ï¼ˆindic., subj., or opt.ï¼‰ = our â€œuntilâ€ in negative sentences. Thus Î¿á½Îº á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á¼ÎºÎ»á½µÎ¸Î· differs from Î¿á½Îº á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ ÎºÎ»Î·Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ by implying that at last he was called, and then came. Here, the form of the sentence is affirmative ï¼ˆá¼ Î³á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ï¼‰, and á¼•Ï‰Ï‚ would therefore be more strictly correct. But the thought is negative ï¼ˆ â€œnothing happened to disturb meâ€ï¼‰; hence Ï€Ïá½·Î½. So Thuc. 3.29 Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î»Î±Î½Î¸á½±Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ ï¼ˆ= Î¿á½Ï‡ á½Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼ˆ.ï¼‰ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Î´á½´ Ï„á¿‡ Î”á½µÎ»á¿³ á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î½. Cp. Whitelaw in Trans. Cam. Phil. Ï„á½´Î½ ÎºÎ¿ÏÎ¹Î½Î¸á½·Î±Î½ â€œHenceforth measuring from afar ï¼ˆá¼ÎºÎ¼ÎµÏ„ÏÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ï¼‰by the stars the region of Corinth, I went my way into exile, to some place where I should not see fulfilled the dishonours of [= foretold by] my evil oracles.â€ á¼„ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎ¼ÎµÏ„ÏÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚: i.e. visiting it no more, but only thinking of it as a distant land that lies beneath the stars in this or that quarter of the heavens. Sense, not grammar, forbids the version: - â€œI went into exile from the Corinthian land ï¼ˆÏ„á½´Î½ ÎšÎ¿ÏÎ¹Î½Î¸á½·Î±Î½ï¼‰,thenceforth measuring my way on earth ï¼ˆÏ‡Î¸á½¹Î½Î±ï¼‰ by the stars.â€ Phrases like á½•Ï€Î±ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½Î¼á¿†Ï‡Î±Ï á½Ïá½·Î¶Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Ï… Î´á½»ÏƒÏ†ÏÎ¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ | Ï†Ï…Î³á¾· ï¼ˆAesch. Such phrases could be used figuratively only of a journey through deserts: as Hesych. explains the proverb á¼„ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ ÏƒÎ·Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹Â· Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½°Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Ïá½µÎ¼Î·Î½ á½Î´á½¸Î½ Î²Î±Î´á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½Â· á¼¡ Î´á½² Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±Ï†Î¿Ïá½° á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î»Îµá½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½.

Line 796

á¼”Î½Î¸Î± = á¼ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎµ á¼”Î½Î¸Î±, as in Soph. Phil. 1466. Ï†Îµá½»Î³Ï‰ á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Î¼á½´ á½„ÏˆÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ = â€œI fly to such a place that I shall not seeâ€; the relative clause expresses purpose, and Î¼á½µ gives a generic force: cp. 1412: Soph. Aj. 659: Soph. El. 380, 436: Soph. Trach. 800. Here, the secondary tense á¼”Ï†ÎµÏ…Î³Î¿Î½ permits á½€ÏˆÎ¿á½·Î¼Î·Î½. Remark, however, that in such relative clauses ï¼ˆof purpose or resultï¼‰ the fut. indic. is usually retained, even where the optat. is admissible. A rare exception is Plat. Rep. 416c. Ï†Î±á½·Î· á¼„Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚Î´Îµá¿–Î½ou)si/an toiau/thn au)toi=s pareskeua/sqai, h(/tis mh/tepau/soi k.t.l.: where Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ ï¼ˆif soundï¼‰ is probably due to Ï†Î±á½·Î· á¼„Î½ ï¼ˆsee on Soph. Line 800

ÎºÎ±á½· ÏƒÎ¿Î¹Ï„ÏÎ¹Ï€Î»á¿†Ï‚ The hand which added this verse in the margin of L seems to be â€œas early as the beginning of the fourteenth centuryâ€ ï¼ˆMr E. M. Thompson, Introd. to Facsimile of Laur. MS.ï¼‰. The verse is in A ï¼ˆ1t(h cent.ï¼‰ and all our other MSS. To eject the verse, as Dindorf and Nauck have done, is utterly unwarrantable. It has a fine dramatic force. Oedipus is now at the critical point: he will hide nothing of the truth from her who is nearest to him. It is part of his character that his earnest desire to know the truth never flinches: cp. 1170.

Line 827

Î á½¹Î»Ï…Î²Î¿Î½ Wunder and others think this verse spurious. But it is, in fact, of essential moment to the development of the plot. Oedipus fears that he has slain Laius, but does not yet dream that Laius was his father. This verse accentuates the point at which his belief now stands, and so prepares us for the next stage of discovery. A few MSS. give á¼Î¾á½³Î¸ÏÎµÏˆÎµ Îºá¼€Î¾á½³Ï†Ï…ÏƒÎµÂ· but the Homeric Ï€Ïá½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á½”ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ ï¼ˆHom. Od. 12.134 Î¸Ïá½³ÏˆÎ±ÏƒÎ± Ï„ÎµÎºÎ¿á¿¦Ïƒá½± Ï„Îµï¼‰ seems out of place here just because it throws a less natural emphasis on á¼Î¾á½³Ï†Ï…ÏƒÎµ.

Ï„á½¹Î½ Î³Îµ Î›Î±á¿“Î¿Ï… Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Iocasta argues: â€œEven if he should admit that the deed was done by one man ï¼ˆa circumstance which would confirm our fears that the deed was yoursï¼‰, at any rate the death of Laius cannot be shown to have happened as the oracle foretold; for Laius was to have been killed by my son, who died in infancy. The oracular art having failed in this instance, I refuse to heed Teiresias when he says that you will yet be found guilty of slaying your father Polybus.â€ Iocasta, bent on cheering Oedipus, merely alludes to the possibility of his being indeed the slayer of Laius ï¼ˆ851ï¼‰, and turns to the comforting aspect of the caseâ€”viz., the undoubted failure of the oracle, on any supposition. Line 878

Ï‡ÏÎ·Ïƒá½·Î¼á¿³Ï‡Ïá¿†Ï„Î±Î¹: where it does not use the foot to any purpose: i.e. the leap is to headlong destruction; it is not one in which the feet can anywhere find a safe landing-place. For the paronomasia cp. Pind. Paus. 8.46.2 Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î´á½² Î¿á½Îº á¼„ÏÎ¾Î±Ï‚ á½ Î‘á½”Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼•Î´Î· Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ á¼€Ï€á½±Î³ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ ï¼ˆi.e. carry off to Italyï¼‰: where á¼€Î½Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± are dedicated objects generally, á¼•Î´Î· images worshipped in temples. Is Sophocles glancing here at the mutilators of the Hermae in 415 B.C., and especially at Alcibiades? We can hardly say more than this:â€”ï¼ˆiï¼‰ There is no positive probability as to the date of the play which can be set against such a view. ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ The language suits it, -nay, might well suggest it; nor does it matter that the á¼™ÏÎ¼Î±á¿–, though á¼€Î½Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± ï¼ˆAndoc. 1.34ï¼‰, were not properly á¼•Î´Î·. ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰ It cannot be assumed that the dramatic art of Sophocles would exclude such a reference. Direct contemporary allusion is, indeed, uncongenial to it. But a light touch like thisâ€”especially in a choral odeâ€”might fitly strike a chord of contemporary feeling in unison with the emotion stirred by the drama itself. I do not see how to affirm or to deny that such a suggestion was meant here. ï¼ˆCp. Soph. OC 1537 n.ï¼‰

Line 931

Î±á½”Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ ï¼ˆSoph. Trach. 1040 á½§Î´â€™ Î±á½”Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ á½¥Ï‚ Î¼â€™ á½¤Î»ÎµÏƒÎµï¼‰ can be nothing but adverb from Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‚ ï¼ˆwith Aeolic accentï¼‰, = â€in that very way â€œ: hence, according to the context, (a) simply â€œlikewise,â€ or (b) in a depreciatory sense, â€œonly thus,â€ â€”i.e. â€œinefficiently,â€ â€œvainly.â€ The custom of the grammarians, to write Î±á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ except when the sense is â€œvainly,â€ seems to have come from associating the word with Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚, or possibly even with Î±á½‘Ï„á½¹Ï‚. For Soph., as for Aesch. and Eur., our MSS. on the whole favour Î±á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚: but their authority cannot be presumed to represent a tradition older than, or independent of, the grammarians. It is, indeed, possible that Î±á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ was an instance of old aspiration on false analogy, â€”as the Attic á¼¡Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚ ï¼ˆAeolic á¼„Î¼Î¼ÎµÏ‚ for á¼€ÏƒÎ¼á½³Ï‚ï¼‰ was wrongly aspirated on the analogy of á½‘Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚ ï¼ˆsee Peile, Greek and Latin Etymology p. 302, who agrees on this with Curtiusï¼‰. In the absence of evidence, however, that Î±á½”Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ was a like instance, it appears most reasonable to write Î±á½”Ï„Ï‰Ï‚.

Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Îµá½ÎµÏ€Îµá½·Î±Ï‚ Îµá¼µÎ½ÎµÎºâ€™Â· á¼€Î»Î»á½° Ï†Ïá½±Î¶â€™ á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 932

Line 967

ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–Î½ ÎºÏ„Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½, which the MSS. give, cannot be pronounced positively wrong; but it can hardly be doubted that Soph. here wrote ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–Î½. Phil. 483, 1084ï¼‰: and the pres. infin. 9 times ï¼ˆSoph. El. 305, 1486: Soph. Aj. 443: Soph. OT 678, 1385: Soph. OC 1773: Soph. Trach. 79, 756: Soph. Phil. 409ï¼‰. Aeschylus certainly has the aor. in Aesch. PB 625 Î¼á½µÏ„Î¿Î¹ Î¼Îµ ÎºÏá½»Ïˆá¿ƒÏ‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î¸â€™ á½…Ï€ÎµÏ Î¼á½³Î»Î»Ï‰ Ï€Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½. Excluding the Laconic á¼°Î´á¿†Î½ in Aristoph. Lys. 117, there are but two instances in Comedy, Aristoph. Birds 366 Ï„á½· Î¼á½³Î»Î»ÎµÏ„â€™â€”á¼€Ï€Î¿Î»á½³ÏƒÎ±Î¹, and Aristoph. Ach. 1159 Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î»Î±Î²Îµá¿–Î½. Cp. W. G. Rutherford, New Phrynichus pp. 420-425, and Goodwin, Greek Moods and Tenses sect. 23.2. The concurrence of tribrachs in the 4th and 5th places gives a semi-lyric character which suits the speaker's agitation.

Ï€Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î¹Î± Bentley on Phalaris ï¼ˆxvii, Dyce ii. 115ï¼‰ quotes Favorinus in Diog. Laert. Plat. 24 as saying that Plato Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿ÏƒÎ¿Ï†á½·á¾³á½ Î½á½¹Î¼Î±ÏƒÎµqeou= pro/noian. Îºá¼€Î½ á½€Î½Îµá½·ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ in dreams also ï¼ˆas well as in this oracleï¼‰; and, as such dreams have proved vain, so may this oracle. Soph. was prob. thinking of the story in Hdt. 6.107 that Hippias had such a dream on the eve of the battle of Marathon, and interpreted it as an omen of his restoration to Athens. The simplest view ofá¼¡ Îšá½¹ÏÎ¹Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î¾ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ á¼€Ï€á¿³ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î¿ is, as Whitelaw says, that it means literally, â€œCorinth was lived-away-from by me,â€ â€”being the passive of á¼Î³á½¼ á¼€Ï€á¿´ÎºÎ¿Ï…Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÎšÎ¿Ïá½·Î½Î¸Î¿Ï…. Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚, á¼¢ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚; sc. á½„Î½ÎµÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½ÎµÎ¹Î»á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ ï¼ˆ1035ï¼‰: â€œwas it at the hands of mother or father ï¼ˆrather than at those of strangersï¼‰ that I received such a brand?â€ The agitated speaker follows the train of his own thoughts, scarcely heeding the interposed remark. á¼¸Î¿. 1060 Î¼á½´ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½, Îµá¼´Ï€ÎµÏ Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÎ±Ï…Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 1060

Since the answer at 1042, Iocasta has known the worst. But she is still fain to spare Oedipus the misery of that knowledge. Meanwhile he thinks that she is afraid lest he should prove to be too humbly born. The tragic power here is masterly.

Line 1062

For the genitive Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î·Ï‚ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ without á¼Îº, cp. Soph. El. 341 Î¿á½–ÏƒÎ±Î½ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚, 366 ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿á¿¦ | Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚. Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î·Ï‚ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„Ïá½·Î´Î¿Ï…Î»Î¿Ï‚, thrice a slave, sprung from the third ï¼ˆservileï¼‰ mother: i.e. from a mother, herself a slave, whose mother and grandmother had also been slaves. No commentator, so far as I know, has quoted the passage which best illustrates this: Theopompus fr. 277 ï¼ˆed. Muller 1. 325ï¼‰ Î Ï…Î¸Î¿Î½á½·ÎºÎ·Î½á¼£ Î’Î±ÎºÏ‡á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼¦Î½ Î´Î¿á½»Î»Î· Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î±á½Î»Î·Ï„Ïá½·Î´Î¿Ï‚, á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î· Î´á½² Î£Î¹Î½á½½Ï€Î·Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î˜Ïá¾´Ï„Ï„Î·Ï‚,w(/ste gi/nesqai mh\ mo/non tri/doulon a)lla\ kai\ tri/pornon au)th/n. Dem. 58.17 Îµá¼° Î³á½°Ï á½€Ï†Îµá½·Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á¿· Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½±Ï€Ï€Î¿Ï… Ï€á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î´Î¹á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ Î¿á¼°á½µÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î´Îµá¿–Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†Îµá½»Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ á½…Ï„Î¹ Ï€Î¿Î½Î·Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼Îº Ï„ÏÎ¹Î³Î¿Î½á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·Î½, â€œif, his grandfather having formerly been a debtor,he shall fancy himself entitled to acquittal because he is a rascal of the third generation.â€ Eustathius Hom. Od. 15. 42-50 quotes from HippÃ´nax á¼ˆÏ†á½³Ï‰ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½±Î´Î¿Ï…Î»Î¿Î½ ï¼ˆBergk fr. 75ï¼‰, i.e. â€œseven times a slave. â€ For the force of Ï„ÏÎ¹â€, cp. also Ï„ÏÎ¹Î³á½·Î³Î±Ï‚, Ï„Ïá½·Ï€ÏÎ±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆthricesold, â€”of a slaveï¼‰, Ï„ÏÎ¹Ï€á½³Î´Ï‰Î½ ï¼ˆa slave who has been thrice in fettersï¼‰. Note how the reference to the female line of servile descent is contrived to heighten the contrast with the real situation.

Line 1072

Iocasta rushes from the scene-to appear no more. Cp. the sudden exit of Haemon ï¼ˆSoph. Ant. 766ï¼‰, of Eurydice ï¼ˆSoph. Ant. 1245ï¼‰, and of Deianeira ï¼ˆSoph. Trach. 813ï¼‰. In each of the two latter cases, the exit silently follows a speech by another person, and the Chorus comments on the departing one's silence. Iocasta, like Haemon, has spoken passionate words immediately before going: and here ÏƒÎ¹Ï‰Ï€á¿†Ï‚ï¼ˆ1075ï¼‰ is more strictly â€œreticenceâ€ than â€œsilence.â€

á½¡Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½á½´ for a woman: though, as it is, her â€œproud spiritâ€ only reaches the point of being sensitive as to a lowly origin. She is proud of her lineage; Oedipus, of what he is. Line 1081

Whatever may have been his human parentage, Oed. is the â€œson of Fortune â€ ï¼ˆsaid in a very different tone from â€œFortunae filiusâ€ in Hor. Sat. 2.6.49ï¼‰: Fortune brings forth the months with their varying events; these months, then, are his brothers, who ere now have known him depressed as well as exalted. He has faith in this Mother, and will not shrink from the path on which she seems to beckon him; he will not be false to his sonship. We might recall Schiller's epigram on the Wolfians; whatever may be the human paternity of the Iliad, â€œhat es doch Eine Mutter nur, Und die ZÃ¼ge der Mutter, Deine unsterblichen ZÃ¼ge, Natur.â€

Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Îµá½– Î´Î¹Î´Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ the beneficent: here absol., usu. with dat., as ÏƒÏ†á¿·Î½ Î´â€™ Îµá½– Î´Î¹Î´Î¿á½·Î· Î–Îµá½»Ï‚, Soph. OC 1435. Not gen. abs., â€œwhile she prospers me, â€ since the poet. Ï„á¿†Ï‚ for Î±á½Ï„á¿†Ï‚ could stand only at the beginning of a sentence or clause, as 1082.

Î¼á¿†Î½á½³Ï‚ Î¼Îµ Î¼Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½³Î³Î±Î½ Î´Î¹á½½ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 1083

Î´Î¹á½½ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î½ not: â€œhave determined that I should be sometimes lowly, sometimes greatâ€; to do this was the part of controlling Î¤á½»Ï‡Î·. Rather: â€œhave distinguished me as lowly or greatâ€: i.e., his life has had chapters of adversity alternating with chapters of prosperity; and the months have marked these off ï¼ˆcp. 723ï¼‰. The metaphor of the months as sympathetic brothers is partly merged in the view of them as divisions of time: see on 866, 1300.

â€œHaving sprung of such parentage ï¼ˆá¼ÎºÏ†á½ºÏ‚, whereas Ï†á½»Ï‚ would be merely â€having been born such â€œï¼‰ I will never afterwards prove ï¼ˆá¼Î¾á½³Î»Î¸Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹, evadam, cp. 1011ï¼‰ another man â€ ï¼ˆá¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚, i.e. false to my own natureï¼‰. The license of Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ at the beginning of 1085 is to be explained on essentially the same principle as Î¼á½³Î»Î±Ï‚ Î´â€™ |, etc. ï¼ˆ29, cp. 785, 791ï¼‰ at the end of a verse; viz. that, where the movement of the thought is rapid, one verse can be treated as virtually continuous with the next: hence, too, Soph. Aj. 986 Î¿á½Ï‡ á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï„á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ | Î´á¿†Ï„â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î´Îµá¿¦ÏÎ¿: Soph. Phil. 66 Îµá¼° Î´â€™ á¼ÏÎ³á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹ | Î¼á½´ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î±. Ï„á½°Î½ Î±á½”ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Î½ â€œthe full-moon of to-morrow, â€ acc. of á¼¡ Î±á½”ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆthere is no adj. Î±á½”ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ï¼‰, as Eur. At Athens the great Dionysia were immediately followed by the Î á½±Î½Î´Î¹â€”Î±, a festival held at full-moon in the middle of the month Elaphebolion ï¼ˆat the beginning of Aprilï¼‰: cp. A. Mommsen Heortol. p. 389, and C. F. Hermann Ant. 2.59. Wolff remarks that, if this play was produced on the last day of the Dionysia, the poet would have known that arrangement long beforehand, and may have intended an allusion to the Î á½±Î½Î´Î¹Î± which his Athenian hearers would quickly seize. This would explain why precisely â€œto-morrow's fullmoon â€ is named. â€”Nauck reads Î±á½–ÏÎ¹ï¼ˆas = Ï„Î±Ï‡á½³Ï‰Ï‚, â€œthe coming â€ full-moonï¼‰: Wecklein, á¼¦ÏÎ¹ï¼ˆdat. of á¼¦Ïï¼‰, â€œthe vernal full-moon â€ â€”that, namely, in Elaphebolion.

Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Î½ ï¼ˆsc. á½¥ÏÎ±Î½ï¼‰: Hdt. 2.47 á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Î±á½Ï„á¿‡ Ï€Î±Î½ÏƒÎµÎ»á½µÎ½á¿³. For the accus., cp. on 1138 Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î±. Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Î½, Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ Ïƒá½³ Î³Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ï„ÏÎ¹á½½Ï„Î±Î½ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1091

Ï€Î±Ï„ÏÎ¹á½½Ï„Î±Î½ since Cithaeron partly belongs to Boeotia; so Plutarch of Chaeroneia calls the Theban Dionysus his Ï€Î±Ï„ÏÎ¹á½½Ï„Î·Î½ Î¸Îµá½¹Î½, Plut. Mor. 671c. â€”I read ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Î½ instead of ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…. With the genitive, the subject to Î±á½”Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ must be either ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ understood, which is impossibly harsh; or ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ Ï„á½°Î½Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Î½. Such a phrase as á¼¡ Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î±á½”Î¾ÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÎµ, i.e., â€œsees thee honoured,â€ is possible; cp. 438 á¼¥Î´â€™ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ± Ï†á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÎµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¹Î±Ï†Î¸ÎµÏÎµá¿–: but it is somewhat forced; and the order of the words is against it. The addition of one letter, giving ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Î½, at once yields a clear construction and a pointed sense. â€œThou shalt not fail to know that Oedipus honours thee both as native to him, and as his nurse and mother ï¼ˆi.e., not merely as belonging to his Theban fatherland, but as the very spot which sheltered his infancyï¼‰; and that thou art celebrated in choral song by us ï¼ˆÏ€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ï¼‰, seeing that thou art well-pleasing to him.â€ Î¼á½´ Î¿á½ with Î±á½”Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½, because Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼”ÏƒÎµÎ¹ = a verb of hindrance or denial with a negative. Î±á½”Î¾ÎµÎ¹Î½, not merely by praises, but by the fact of his birth in the neighbourhood: as Pindar says of a victor in the games, Pind. O. 5.4 Ï„á½°Î½ Ïƒá½°Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ Î±á½”Î¾Ï‰Î½, Pind. P. 8.38 Î±á½”Î¾Ï‰Î½ Ï€á½±Ï„ÏÎ±Î½. The acc. Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±, instead of Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰Î½, may be explained by supposing that Ïƒá½³ Î³Îµ is carried on as subject to Ï‡Î¿ÏÎµá½»ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹: cp. Soph. Trach. 706 n. Another defence of the acc. would be to take ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡Î¿Ï. Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ as a parenthesis ï¼ˆcp. Soph. Ant. 1279 n.ï¼‰: so Tyrrell in Class. Rev. 2.141.

Î¿á¼¶ÏƒÎ¸Î± with Î¼Î±Î¸á½½Î½, are you aware of having observed this man here? Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎšÎ¹Î¸Î±Î¹Ïá¿¶Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î½ The sentence begins as if it were meant to proceed thus: Ï„á½¸Î½ Îš. á¼Ï€Î»Î·Ïƒá½·Î±Î¶Î¿Î½ Ï„á¿·Î´Îµ Ï„á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¶ Ï„ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚ á½…Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚
á¼Î¾ á¼¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎºÏ„Î¿á¿¦ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼‘ÎºÎ¼á½µÎ½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚Â· ğŸ—©
Line 1137

á¼Î¾ á¼¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎºÏ„Î¿á¿¦ÏÎ¿Î½ from March to September. In March the herd of Polybus drove his flock up to Cithaeron from Corinth, and met the herd of Laius, who had brought up his flock from the plain of Thebes. For six months they used to consort in the upland glens of Cithaeron; then, in September, when Arcturus began to be visible a little before dawn, they parted, taking their flocks for the winter into homesteads near Corinth and Thebes.

á¼€ÏÎºÏ„Î¿á¿¦ÏÎ¿Î½ ï¼ˆthe star Î± of the constellation Bootes,ï¼‰ first so called in Hes. WD 566 where ï¼ˆ610ï¼‰ his appearance as a morning star is the signal for the vintage. Hippoc. Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…: the statement in Lidd. and Scott's Lexicon ï¼ˆt\h ed.ï¼‰ that it is feminine was due to a misunderstanding of the words Ï€Î»á½´Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼±ÎµÏá¾¶Ï‚ ï¼ˆsc. Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï…ï¼‰ just afterwards. Aristotle also has this form. Cp. á¼•ÎºÏ€Î»ÎµÎ¸ÏÎ¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆEur.ï¼‰, á¼•ÎºÏ€Î¿Ï…Ï‚, á¼•ÎºÏ€Î»ÎµÏ…ÏÎ¿Ï‚. The form á¼‘Î¾Î¼á½³Î´Î¹Î¼Î½Î¿Î½ in Aristoph. Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î± Î´â€™ á¼¤Î´Î· Ï„á¼€Î¼á½± Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î±Ï…Î»â€™ á¼Î³á½¼ ğŸ—©
Line 1138

The fact that L has Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î± without notice of a variant, while some other MSS. notice it as a variant on their Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î¹, is in favour of the accus., the harder reading. It may be rendered â€œfor the winter,â€ since it involves the notion of the time during which the flock was to remain in the á¼”Ï€Î±Ï…Î»Î±. It is, however, one of those temporal accusatives which are almost adverbial, the idea of duration being merged in that of season, so that they can even be used concurrently with a temporal genitive: Hdt. 3.117 Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î± á½•ÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÏ†Î¹ á½ Î¸Îµá½¹Ï‚Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½² Î¸á½³ÏÎµÎ¿Ï‚ ÏƒÏ€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚xrhi/+skonto tw=| u(/dati. 2.95 Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ·Ï‚ á¼°Ï‡Î¸á¿¦Ï‚ á¼€Î³ÏÎµá½»ÎµÎ¹, Ï„á½´Î½ Î´á½² Î½á½»ÎºÏ„Î± Ï„á½±Î´Îµ Î±á½Ï„á¿· Ï‡Ïá¾¶Ï„Î±Î¹. 2.2 Ï„á½´Î½ á½¥ÏÎ·Î½ á¼Ï€Î±Î³Î¹Î½á½³ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÏƒÏ†Î¹ Î±á¼¶Î³Î±Ï‚, â€œat the due season.â€ 7.151 Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚á¼€Î³Î³á½³Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚. Cp. above, 1090 Ï„á½°Î½ Î±á½”ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½³Î»Î·Î½Î¿Î½. The tendency to such a use of the accus. may have been an old trait of the popular language ï¼ˆcp. á¼€Ï‰Ïá½·Î±Î½ á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Aristoph. Ach. 23, ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Î½ á¼Ï†á½µÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Soph. Aj. 34ï¼‰. Modern Greek regularly uses the accus. for the old temporal dat.: e. g. Ï„á½´Î½ Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î·Î½ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î½ for Ï„á¿‡ Ï„Ïá½·Ï„á¿ƒ á¼¡Î¼á½³Ïá¾³. Classical prose would here use the genit.: Thuc. 1.30 Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼¤Î´Î· á¼€Î½ÎµÏ‡á½½ÏÎ·ÏƒÎ±Î½. The division of the year implied is into á¼”Î±Ï, Î¸á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆincluding á½€Ï€á½½ÏÎ±ï¼‰, and Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á½½Î½ ï¼ˆincluding Ï†Î¸Î¹Î½á½¹Ï€Ï‰ÏÎ¿Î½ï¼‰.

á¼¤Î»Î±Ï…Î½Î¿Î½ Î¿á½—Ï„á½¹Ï‚ Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½° Î›Î±á¿“Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¸Î¼á½±.

á½¡Ï‚ with á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼á¿¶Â· Ï„á½¸ Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ adverbially with Î¶á½½ÏƒÎ±Ï‚: i.e. how absolutely do I count you as living a life which is no life. ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÎ²Î¿Î»á½°Î½ Ï„Î¿Î¾Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ having hit the answer to the riddle of the Sphinx, when Teiresias and all others had failed: cp. 398: Aesch. Ag. 628 á¼”ÎºÏ…ÏÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ Ï„Î¿Î¾á½¹Ï„Î·Ï‚ á¼„ÎºÏÎ¿Ï‚ ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿á¿¦.

á¼ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·ÏƒÎµ At 1193 the Chorus addressed Oedipus: at 1197 ï¼ˆá½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î».ï¼‰ they turn to invoke Zeus as the witness of his achievements; and so in 1200 L, which here has the corrupt á¼ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, rightly gives á¼€Î½á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±. To read á¼ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ and á¼€Î½á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï‚ would be to efface a fine trait, marking the passion of grief which turns from earth to heaven, and then again to earth.

á¼°á½¼ Î›Î±á¿“ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ á½§ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½ Erfurdt's á½¦ is the most probable way of supplying the required syllable, and Reisig's objection to its place is answered by Soph. á¼¼ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½ the Thracian name for the lower course of the river which the Kelts called Danuvius ï¼ˆfor this rather than Danubius is the correct form, Kiepert Anc. Geo. Â§196 n., Byzantine and modern Î”Î¿á½»Î½Î±Î²Î¹Ï‚ï¼‰.

Î¦á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ï¼ˆRionï¼‰, dividing Colchis from Asia Minor and flowing into the Euxine. ï¼ˆ â€œPhasis â€ in Xen. Anab. 4.6.4 must mean the Araxes, which flows into the Caspian.ï¼‰ Soph. names these simply as great rivers, not with conscious choice as representatives of Europe and Asia. Ovid Met. 2.248 arsit Orontes | Thermodonque citus Gangesque et Phasis et Ister. Commentators compare Seneca Hipp. 715 Quis eluet me Tanais? aut quae barbaris Maeotis undis Pontico incumbens mari? Non ipse toto magnus Oceano pater Tantum piarit sceleris, and Shaksp. Macbeth 2.2.60 â€œWill all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand?â€: where, however, the agony of personal remorse renders the hyperbole somewhat more natural than it is here in the mouth of a messenger.

Line 1241

We are to suppose that, when she rushed from the scene in her passionate despair ï¼ˆ1072ï¼‰, Iocasta passed through the central door of the palace ï¼ˆÎ²Î±Ïƒá½·Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Î¸á½»ÏÎ±ï¼‰ into the Î¸Ï…Ïá½½Î½, a short passage or hall, opening on the court ï¼ˆÎ±á½Î»á½µï¼‰ surrounded by a colonnade ï¼ˆÏ€ÎµÏá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î»Î¿Î½ï¼‰. Across this court she hurried to the Î¸á½±Î»Î±Î¼Î¿Ï‚ or bedroom of the master and mistress of the house, and shut herself into it. Presently Oedipus burst into the court with that cry of which we heard the first accents ï¼ˆ1182ï¼‰ as he fled from the scene ï¼ˆÎ²Î¿Ï‰Î½ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½³Ï€Î±Î¹ÏƒÎµÎ½,1252ï¼‰. The messenger and others who were in the court watch him in terror as he raves for a sword and asks for Iocasta. Then the thought strikes him that she is in the Î¸á½±Î»Î±Î¼Î¿Ï‚. He bursts into it ï¼ˆá¼Î½á½µÎ»Î±Ï„Î¿1261ï¼‰. They follow. There they find Iocasta dead, and see Oedipus blind himself.

Îµá½Î¸á½º â€œstraight,â€ is obviously more forcible here than Îµá½Î¸á½»Ï‚, â€œwithout delayâ€; a distinction to which Eur. Hipp. 1197 Ï„á½´Î½ Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼ŒÏÎ³Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Îºá¼€Ï€Î¹Î´Î±Ï…Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ á½Î´á½¹Î½ is an exception rare in classical Attic. Nauck, with tasteless caprice, writes Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼Ï‚.

Î³Î¿á¾¶Ï„Î¿ Î´â€™ Îµá½Î½á½±Ï‚, á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¹Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 1249

Î³Î¿á¾¶Ï„Î¿ Cp. Curt. Verb 1.138, Eng. tr. 92: â€œIt seems to me best on all grounds to suppose that shortly before the rise of the Greek Epic the [syllabic] augment became occasionally exposed to the same tendency towards wearing away ï¼ˆVerwitterungï¼‰ which the á¼€ of á¼„ÏÎ± and the á¼ of á¼”Î½ÎµÏÎ¸Îµ could not always withstand; that there were, in short, pairs of forms then in use, one with the augment and one withoutThe omission of the syllabic augment in Homer was purely a matter of choicePost-Homeric poetry adopts the power of dispensing with the syllabic augment as an inheritance from its predecessor, and makes the greater use of it in proportion as it is removed from the language of ordinary life. Hence it is that, as is shown by the careful investigations made by Renner ï¼ˆStud. 1.2.18 ff.ï¼‰, the omission of the syllabic augment is extremely rare in iambic, and far more common in elegiac and lyric verse. Hence, as is shown ï¼ˆStud. 1.2.259ï¼‰ by Gerth, in the dialogue of tragedy the range of this license is very limited indeed, while the majority of instances of it occur in the slightly Epic style of the messengersâ€ speeches, or still more commonly in lyric passages. â€œ The tragic á¿¥á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ here borrow from a practice more marked in epic narrative than in epic speeches. In Homer, where augmented and unaugmented forms are on the whole about equally numerous, the proportion of augmented to unaugmented is in the speeches about 10 to 3, in the narrative about 5 to 7: see Monro, Hom. Grammar sect. 69.

Î´Î¹Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ acc. plur., a twofold progeny, viz. ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ Oedipus by Laius ï¼ˆá¼Î¾ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ±ï¼‰, and ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ her four children by Oedipus ï¼ˆÏ„á½³ÎºÎ½Î± á¼Îº Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½, where the poetical plur. Here the â€œbasesâ€ of the ÎºÎ»á¿‡Î¸ÏÎ± ï¼ˆboltsï¼‰ are the staples or sockets which held them. They were on the inner side of the doors, which Iocasta had closed behind her ï¼ˆ1244ï¼‰. The pressure of Oedipus on the outer side forces the bolts, causing them to bend inwards ï¼ˆÎºÎ¿á¿–Î»Î±ï¼‰.So Oedipus, within the house, gives the order Î´Î¹Î¿á½·Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ»á¿‡Î¸ÏÎ±, 1287. Ï€ÎµÏá½¹Î½Î±Ï‚ ï¼ˆcalled Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¹ by Eur. Phoen. 62ï¼‰, brooches with long pins which could serve as small daggers: one fastened Iocasta's á¼±Î¼á½±Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½ on her left shoulder, and another her Doric Ï‡Î¹Ï„á½½Î½ on the right shoulder, which the á¼±Î¼á½±Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½ did not cover. The Doric Ï‡Î¹Ï„á½½Î½ was sleeveless, and usually made with a slit at each shoulder, requiring the use of brooches. ï¼ˆCp. Guhl and Koner, Life of the Greeks and Romans, p. 162 Eng. tr.ï¼‰ In â€œThe Harvard Greek Playâ€ ï¼ˆ1882ï¼‰, plate 11. p. 26 represents Iocasta with the á¼±Î¼á½±Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½ thus worn. Cp. Hdt. 5.87, where the Athenian women surround the sole survivor of the expedition to Aegina, ÎºÎµÎ½Ï„Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï„á¿‡ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€ÎµÏá½¹Î½á¿ƒÏƒÎ¹ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼±Î¼Î±Ï„á½·Ï‰Î½, and so slay him. Thus too in Eur. The best choice lies between Heath's á½„Î¼Î²ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï‡Î±Î»á½±Î¶Î·Ï‚ Î±á¼±Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ and Porson's á½„Î¼Î²ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï‡á½±Î»Î±Î¶á½± Î¸â€™ Î±á¼±Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÏƒâ€™. á¼”Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½Î¹ is right. Even if Ï„á½·Ï‚ ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á½´ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿¦ could mean â€œwhat form of respite from misery?â€ Ï„á½·Î½Î¹ would be less suitable. The Chorus mean: â€œand is he now calmer?â€ â€”to which the answer is that he is still vehemently excited.

The central door of the palace is now opened. Oedipus comes forth, leaning on attendants; the bloody stains are still upon his face.

á½…ÏƒÎ±Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½³ÎºÏ…ÏÏƒÎ± I know no other example of an accus. after Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÏ…ÏÎµá¿–Î½, which usu. takes the dat.: but the compound can at least claim the privilege of the simple ÎºÏ…ÏÎµá¿–Î½. Line 1303

The Attic Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½â€™ harmonises with Ïƒá¿‡ ï¼ˆ1302ï¼‰ and Ï†Ïá½·ÎºÎ·Î½ ï¼ˆ1306ï¼‰, while Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î±Î½â€™ would hardly be confirmed by Î¼Î±Îºá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½, since Tragedy used the latter form, and not Î¼á½µÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚, in dialogue also ï¼ˆAesch. fr. 275: cp. Î´Î¹Î±Ï€á½³Ï„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹ ï¼ˆMSS.ï¼‰ is unquestionably corrupt. The view that these are anapaests of the â€œfreer kind â€ ï¼ˆ â€œex liberioribus, â€ Herm.ï¼‰ does not explain a verse which is not anapaestic at all. Î´Î¹Î±Ï€Ï‰Ï„á¾¶Ï„Î±Î¹ is far the most probable remedy. The epic Ï€Ï‰Ï„á¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, which Pind. uses, is admissible in lyrics. Ï†Î¿Ïá½±Î´Î·Î½ = â€œin the manner of that which is carried â€; here correlative to Ï†á½³ÏÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ as said of things which are swept onward by a tide or current: thus, of persons deficient in self-restraint, Plat. Such adverbs in â€Î´Î·Î½, which were probably accusatives cognate to the notion of the verb, are always formed from the verbal stem, (a) directly, like Î²á½±â€Î´Î·Î½, or (b) with modified vowel and inserted Î±, like Ï†Î¿Ïá½±Î´Î·Î½ instead of * Ï†ÎµÏÎ´Î·Î½, ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ïá½±Î´Î·Î½ instead of * ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏÎ´Î·Î½.

Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¿á½»ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ is defective by one syllable as compared with 1323 Ï„Ï…Ï†Î»á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ·Î´Îµá½»Ï‰Î½. Now the second syllable of ÎºÎ·Î´Îµá½»Ï‰Î½ is â€œirrational, â€ i.e. it is a long syllable doing metrical duty for a short one ï¼ˆthe third of an antibacchius, \h\\h\\v\ï¼‰. Hence in this verse also the penultimate syllable can be either long or short. Hermann's Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¿á½»ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ á½„Î½ is therefore metrically admissible. Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½ The form of the sentence, in dependence on Î¸Î±á¿¦Î¼Î± Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½, seems to exclude the version: â€œIt is not strange that, as you bear, so you should mourn, a double pain â€ ï¼ˆparataxis for hypotaxisï¼‰. á½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½° ÎºÎ±Îºá½° Îº.Ï„.Î». The dochmiac metre is sound ï¼ˆsee Metrical Analysisï¼‰: it is Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚ in the antistrophe ï¼ˆ1350ï¼‰ which is corrupt. But here, at least, it is in place.

Line 1348

á¼‚Î½ with á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ±Â· Î³Îµ emphasises Î¼Î·Î´á½³. Oedipus had been the all-admired ï¼ˆ8ï¼‰, the â€œsaviour of the land â€ ï¼ˆ48ï¼‰. But now the Theban elders wish that they had never so much as heard his name or looked upon his face. That bitter cry is drawn from them by the very strength of their sympathy: for his ruin was the result of his coming to Thebes. The objections to the reading of the MSS., á½¥Ï‚ Ïƒâ€™ á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ± Î¼Î·Î´â€™ á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î½á¿¶Î½Î±á½· Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ, are these: ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ Eur. Hel. 290 has the 1st aor. pass., á¼€Î½ÎµÎ³Î½á½½ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î¼ÎµÎ½ á¼„Î½, â€œwe should have been recognised â€: but á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î¹Î³Î½á½½ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î½ occurs nowhere else in tragedy; and in Attic its regular sense was â€œto read,â€ or in the 1st aor. act., â€œto persuade.â€ I have not found a single example of á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î¹Î³Î½á½½ÏƒÎºÏ‰ as = á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î½Ï‰Ïá½·Î¶Ï‰ ï¼ˆ â€œto recognise â€ï¼‰ in Thuc., Plato, Xen., or the Orators. ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ But the 2nd aor. has that sense in Homer, in Pind. I. 2.23 and in Hdt. 2.91: may not an Attic poet have followed them? Granted. The sense required here, however, after Î¼Î·Î´á½³, is to know, not to recognise: the latter would be pointless. ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰ The ellipse of á¼„Î½ with the aor. á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ± would be strangely harsh. Such an ellipse with the imperf. sometimes occurs: as Antiph. 5.1 á¼Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ ï¼ˆand so Aristoph. Frogs 866ï¼‰, Antiph. 5.86 á¼ Î¾á½·Î¿Ï…Î½. But if, as seems clear, á¼„Î½ is required here, then the probability is strengthened that á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î½á¿¶Î½Î±Î¹ arose from á¼‚Î½ Î³Î½á¿¶Î½Î±Î¹. Between Dindorf's á½¡Ï‚ á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ± Î¼Î·Î´á½³ Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½ Î³Î½á¿¶Î½Î±Î¹ and Hermann's á½¥Ï‚ Ïƒâ€™ á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎ± Î¼Î·Î´á½³ Î³â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î³Î½á¿¶Î½Î±Î¹ the question is: Which is more likely to have passed into the reading of the MSS.? Line 1350

The Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚ of the MSS. is corrupt. It would require an improbable alteration in the strophe ï¼ˆsee on 1330ï¼‰; and it yields no good sense. The Scholiasts hesitated between rendering it ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ â€œfeeding on my flesh â€! or ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ â€œin the pastures.â€ Reading Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´â€™, we have a dochmiac dimeter, agreeing with 1330: see Metrical Analysis. But the use of the word is extraordinary. It must mean á¼Î½ Î½Î¿Î¼Î±á¿–Ï‚, â€œin the pasturesâ€â€”said of the babe whom the shepherd had been ordered to expose on Cithaeron. Now elsewhere Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Ï‚ always means â€œroaming,â€ said ï¼ˆe.g.ï¼‰ of pastoral tribes, or of animals: Soph. Trach. 271 á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´Î±Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î¹Ï‡Î½Î¿ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€á¿¶Î½, tracking horse that had strayed: fr. 87 Î½Î¿Î¼á½°Ï‚ Î´á½³ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎµÏÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÏƒâ€™ á¼€Ï€â€™ á½€ÏÎ¸á½·Ï‰Î½ Ï€á½±Î³Ï‰Î½ | ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–ÏÏ€ÎµÎ½ á¼”Î»Î±Ï†Î¿Ï‚: of waters wandering over the land which they irrigate, Soph. OC 686 ÎºÏá¿†Î½Î±Î¹| ÎšÎ·Ï†Î¹ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´ÎµÏ‚ á¿¥Îµá½³Î¸ÏÏ‰Î½. The idea of wandering movement is inseparable from the word. To apply it to a babe whose feet were pinned together would have been indeed a bold use. Prof. Campbell, retaining Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚, takes Ï€á½³Î´Î±Ï‚ as acc. plur.: â€œthat loosed the cruel clog upon my feet, when I was sent astray.â€ But could Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Ï‚, â€˜roaming, â€™ be said of the maimed child merely in the sense of â€˜turned adriftâ€™ by its parents? The nomin. Î½Î¿Î¼á½°Ï‚, referring to the roving shepherd ï¼ˆÏ€Î»á½±Î½Î·Ï‚ 1029ï¼‰ would be intelligible; but the quadruple â€Î±Ï‚ is against it. Now cp. Aesch. Pers. 734 Î¼Î¿Î½á½±Î´Î± Î´á½² Îá½³ÏÎ¾Î·Î½ á¼”ÏÎ·Î¼Î¿Î½, â€œXerxes alone and forlorn. â€ Simply transposing Î½ and Î¼ I conjecture Î¼Î¿Î½á½±Î´â€™, a word appropriate to the complaint that the babe, sent to the lonely mountain, had not been left to perish in its solitude. The fact that the Corinthian shepherd received the child from the Theban is no objection: the child was Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚, desolate and forlorn. á¼”Î»Ï…Ïƒâ€™, which suits the dochmiac as well as á¼”Î»Î±Î²á½³ Î¼â€™, is more forcible here. There is a further argument for it. The MSS. give á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼€Î³Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ in 1349, but the strophe ï¼ˆ1329ï¼‰ shows that á¼€Ï€â€™ must be omitted, since á¼ˆÏ€á½¹Î»Î»Ï‰Î½, Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹ = á½ƒÏ‚ á¼€Î³Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ Ï€á½³Î´Î±Ï‚, the first syllable of á¼€Î³Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ being short, as in 1205, Soph. á¼€Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Îµ Ï„Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ¼Î± By the change of one letter, we restore sense to the passage. The Ï„Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ of the MSS. is unintelligible. Line 1415

No one can share the burden of his ills. Other men need not fear to be polluted by contact with him, as with one guilty of blood. His unwitting crimes and his awful sufferingsâ€”alike the work of Apolloâ€”place him apart. In illustration of the fear which he seeks to allay, compare the plea of Orestes that, since he has been duly purified from bloodshed, contact with him has ceased to be dangerous ï¼ˆAesch. There, he feels that he is still formally á¼„Î½Î±Î³Î½Î¿Ï‚, and that gratitude forbids him to impart a possible taint. Here, he thinks only of his unique doom and his incommunicable anguish.

Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï†Î±Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼”Î½Î´Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚; â€œwhat reasonable claim to confidence can be produced on my part?â€ Oedipus had brought a charge against Creon which was false, and had repudiated a charge against himself which was true. ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÎ¿á½· Î³â€™ yes [I am prepared to abide by Apollo's word], and on thee too I lay an injunction, and I will now make a prayer to thee; i.e. as I turn to the god for what he alone can give ï¼ˆcp. 1519 Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿¦ Î¼â€™ Î±á¼°Ï„Îµá¿–Ï‚ Î´á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ï¼‰, so I turn to thee for that which lies in thine own power. There is no cause to desire á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎºá½µÏˆÏ‰: each tense has its due force: I now enjoin, and am going on to ask. Just so in Thuc. 2.44 Î¿á½Îº á½€Î»Î¿Ï†á½»ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼¢ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î¼Ï…Î¸á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹, where the conjecture á½€Î»Î¿Ï†Ï…ÏÎ¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹ is needless: â€œI do not bewail them, but rather intend to comfort them. â€ The reading Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„Ïá½³ÏˆÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ must be judged by the context. With it, the sense is: â€”yes [I am sensible of my duty to Apollo], and I enjoin on thee, and will exhort thee, to do thine. ï¼ˆCp. 358 Ï€ÏÎ¿á½Ï„Ïá½³ÏˆÏ‰; Plat. Laws 711b Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎµÏ„á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„Î·Î´Îµá½»Î¼Î±Ï„Î± Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„Ïá½³Ï€ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï€Î¿Î»á½·Ï„Î±Ï‚.ï¼‰ But this strain of lofty admonition seems little in accord with the tone of the broken man who has just acknowledged Creon's unexpected goodness ï¼ˆ1432ï¼‰, and is now a suppliant ï¼ˆcp. 1468ï¼‰. Line 1453

The words á¼Î¾ á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ form the decisive argument for the Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„Îµ of the MSS. against Toup's specious emendation, Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹. His parents in their life-time appointed Cithaeron to be his grave. Now they are dead; but, though he can no longer die by their agency, he wishes to die á¼Î¾ á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½, by their doom; i.e. by selfexposure in the same wilds to which they had consigned him ï¼ˆcp. 719 á¼”ÏÏÎ¹ÏˆÎµÎ½ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼„Î²Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ á½„ÏÎ¿Ï‚ï¼‰. The thought of the dead bringing death upon the living is one which Sophocles has also in Soph. Aj. 1026 Îµá¼¶Î´ÎµÏ‚ á½¡Ï‚ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ | á¼”Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½³ Ïƒâ€™ á¼ÎºÏ„Ï‰Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸Î±Î½á½¼Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†Î¸Î¹Îµá¿–Î½; Soph. Trach. 1163 ï¼ˆHeracles speaking of Nessusï¼‰ Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„á½± Î¼â€™ á¼”ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î½ÎµÎ½ Î¸Î±Î½á½½Î½: Soph. Ant. 871. The reading Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹, on the other hand, yields nothing but a weak verbal antithesis with Ï„á½±Ï†Î¿Î½. Had his parents meant him to live in lonely misery on Cithaeron, there would be some point in calling it his â€œliving grave. â€ But they meant him to die there forthwith ï¼ˆcp. 1174ï¼‰; Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹, then, would mean nothing more than that the grave was chosen before the babe was dead.

Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± Î¼á½´ á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎ±Î¹ = â€œI am confident that nothing can destroy me â€ Î¼á½µ is admissible since Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± here = Ï€á½³Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¸Î±, and Î¼á½´ á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎ±Î¹ represents a negative conception of the mind. So with partic. Soph. OC 656 Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½½ ÏƒÎµ Î¼á½µ Ï„Î¹Î½Î± | á¼Î½Î¸á½³Î½Î´â€™ á¼€Ï€á½±Î¾Î¿Î½Ï„â€™. Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎ±Î¹ would be more usual; the difference being that this would be the oblique form of Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± á½…Ï„Î¹ Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎµÎ¹Îµ. The ordinary usage is ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ Î¿á½ with infin. (= á½…Ï„Î¹ with indic.ï¼‰ after verbs of saying or thinking, Î»á½³Î³Ï‰, Ï†Î·Î¼á½·, Î¿á¼´Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹, etc; ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ Î¼á½µ with infin. after verbs of feeling confident, promising, etc., as Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½»Ï‰, Ï€á½³Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¸Î±, á½‘Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ‡Î½Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹, á½„Î¼Î½Ï…Î¼Î¹. But a few exceptions occur both ways, when a verb of either class is virtually equivalent to a verb of the other: e.g. (1) Dem. 29.48 Î¿á¼´ÎµÏƒÎ¸Îµ Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½´Î½ Î»Î±Î²Îµá¿–Î½ ï¼ˆ= á½…Ï„Î¹ Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ á¼”Î»Î±Î²ÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á½µÎ½ï¼‰, but Xen. Mem. 1.2.41 Î¿á¼¶Î¼Î±Î¹ Î¼á½´ á¼‚Î½ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±á½·Ï‰Ï‚ Ï„Ï…Ï‡Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼Ï€Î±á½·Î½Î¿Ï… Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½´ Îµá¼°Î´á½¹Ï„Î±: (2) Plat. Prot. 336b á½Î¼Î¿Î»Î¿Î³Îµá¿– Î¼á½´ Î¼ÎµÏ„Îµá¿–Î½Î±á½· Î¿á¼± Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ¿Î»Î¿Î³á½·Î±Ï‚, but Plat. Apol. 17a á½Î¼Î¿Î»Î¿Î³Î¿á½·Î·Î½ á¼‚Î½ á¼”Î³Ï‰Î³Îµ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ á¿¥á½µÏ„Ï‰Ï. Cp. Whitelaw in Trans. Cam. Phil. Soc. ï¼ˆ1886ï¼‰ p. 34, and Gildersleeve in Amer. Fourn. Philol. 1.49. â€”Whitelaw here takes Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎ±Î¹ á¼„Î½ as = á¼”Ï€ÎµÏÏƒÎµÎ½ á¼„Î½, and reads Ï„á¿· ï¼ˆnot Ï„á¿³ï¼‰ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿· ÎºÎ±Îºá¿·: â€œmy parents wished to kill me; but nothing could have killed me; I was reserved for this dread evil. â€ Surely, however, it is better to connect the verses with the wish for death which he has just uttered. The poet of Colonus gives Oedipus a presentiment that his end is not to be as that of other men.

Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿–Î¼â€™ for this form, cp. Soph. Phil. 895 Î´Ïá¿·Î¼â€™ ï¼ˆn.ï¼‰. á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÏƒÏ†Î±Ï‚. ÏƒÏ†á½³Î±Ï‚ has the accent in Homer when it is emphatic, as when joined with Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½»Ï‚, being then a disyllable: Hom. Il. 12.43 ÏƒÏ†á½³Î±Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½»Ï‚. Here, as in 1508, the pronoun is non-emphatic. According to the rule now generally received, a monosyllabic enclitic stands unaccented after a paroxytone word, the latter remaining unaffected: we therefore write á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÏƒÏ†Î±Ï‚. But, according to Arcadius and Herodian, a paroxytone word followed by an enclitic beginning with Ï‚ Ï† took the acute on its last syllable, as á¼”Ï‡Îµá½·Î½ ÏƒÏ†Î±Ï‚: see Chandler, Â§Â§965, 966, 2nd ed.
