Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ á¼±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ïá¿¶Î½ i.e. neither recognising his mother when he saw her, nor possessing any information which could lead him to suspect that she was such. á¼±ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎµá¿–Î½ is ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ to be, or ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ to become, á¼µÏƒÏ„Ï‰Ï, a knower: i.e. ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ to have information, or ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ to seek it. ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ†á½¼ Î´Î±ÎºÏá½»Ï‰Â· Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ²Î»á½³Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï‰Â·
Î½Î¿Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½° Î»Î¿Î¹Ï€á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏÎ¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï…,

Ï€Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼€ÏƒÏ„á¿¶Î½ á¼¥Î¾ÎµÏ„â€™ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á½Î¼Î¹Î»á½·Î±Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 1489

á½Î¼Î¹Î»á½·Î±Ï‚á¼‘Î¿ÏÏ„á½±Ï‚ The poet is thinking of his own Athens, though the language is general. á½Î¼Î¹Î»á½·Î±Ï‚ comprises all occasions on which Attic women could appear in public, â€”as at the delivery of á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„á½±Ï†Î¹Î¿Î¹ ï¼ˆThuc. 2.45ï¼‰: á¼‘Î¿ÏÏ„á½±Ï‚ suggests such festivals as the Thesmophoria, the Panathenaea, or the Dionysia ï¼ˆwhen women were present in the theatre, at least at tragedyï¼‰. To feel the force of this passage, we must remember how closely the Greek festivals were bound up with the life of the family. Kinsfolk took part in them together: and at such moments a domestic disgrace, such as that which the sisters inherited, would be most keenly felt. In Athenian law-courts the fact of association at festivals could be cited in evidence of family intimacy: Isoc. 19.10 á¼•Ï‰Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚ á¼¦Î¼ÎµÎ½, Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼¡Î³Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ¸Î± á¼¢ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†Î¿á½»Ï‚, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î¸Ï…Ïƒá½·Î±Î½ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î¸ÎµÏ‰Ïá½·Î±Î½ ï¼ˆpublic spectacleï¼‰ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î·Î½ á¼‘Î¿ÏÏ„á½´Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ¼á½·Î±Î½ Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½¶Ï‚ á¼€Î»Î»á½µÎ»Ï‰Î½ á¼¤Î³Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½. Isaeus 8.15 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î”Î¹Î¿Î½á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î± Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼€Î³Ïá½¸Î½ á¼¦Î³ÎµÎ½ á¼€Îµá½¶ á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼ÎµÏ„â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Ï… Ï„Îµ á¼Î¸ÎµÏ‰ÏÎ¿á¿¦Î¼ÎµÎ½ ï¼ˆin the theatreï¼‰ ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼‘Î¿ÏÏ„á½°Ï‚ á¼¤Î³Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚. It was the Attic custom for a bridegroom Î˜ÎµÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¹Î± á¼‘ÏƒÏ„Î¹á¾¶Î½ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎ±Ï‚, to provide a banquet at the next Thesmophoria for the women of his deme ï¼ˆIsaeus 3.80ï¼‰, and also Ï†Ïá½±Ï„Î¿ÏÏƒÎ¹ Î³Î±Î¼Î·Î»á½·Î±Î½ Îµá¼°ÏƒÏ†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½, to provide a banquet for his clansmen when his bride was introduced into his Ï†ÏÎ±Ï„Ïá½·Î± ï¼ˆIsaeus 8.18ï¼‰.

Line 1490

ÎºÎµÎºÎ»Î±Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î±Î¹ only poet.: later poets and Plut. have Îºá½³ÎºÎ»Î±Ï…ÏƒÎ¼Î±Î¹: the poet. Î´ÎµÎ´Î±ÎºÏÏ…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ also occurs in later prose, Plut., Lucian, etc. The festivals were religious celebrations, which would be polluted by the presence of persons resting under an inherited á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ ï¼ˆcp. note on 240ï¼‰. Some word or act reminds the daughters of Oedipus that they are thus regarded, and they go home in tears. Greek sensitiveness to public notice on such occasions might be illustrated by the story in Herodotus of the affront offered to the deposed king Demaratus by his successor Leotychides at the Spartan festival of the Î³Ï…Î¼Î½Î¿Ï€Î±Î¹Î´á½·Î±Î¹ ï¼ˆHdt. 6.67ï¼‰. á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÏ‰Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ in place of the sight-seeing ï¼ˆfor which they had lookedï¼‰. Î¸ÎµÏ‰Ïá½·Î± is ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ subjectively, a sight-seeing: ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ objectively, a spectacle. Îµá¼°Ï‡á½³Ï„Î·Î½ 2nd pers. dual, with the form proper to the 3rd ï¼ˆÎ¼ÎµÏ„ÎµÎ¹Ï‡á½³Ï„Î·Î½, 1465ï¼‰. Before the Attic period, the Greek language had attained to this regular distinction of active dual forms: â€”ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ primary tenses, 2nd pers. â€Ï„Î¿Î½, 3rd pers. â€Ï„Î¿Î½; ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ secondary tenses, 2nd pers. â€Ï„Î¿Î½, answering to Skt. tam: 3rd pers. â€Ï„Î·Î½, Skt. tÄm. As regards ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰, two classes of exceptions occur: ï¼ˆaï¼‰ Homeric 3rd pers. in â€Ï„Î¿Î½ instead of â€Ï„Î·Î½; three instances, Î´Î¹á½½ÎºÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ ï¼ˆHom. Il. 10.364ï¼‰, á¼Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ ï¼ˆHom. Il. 13.346ï¼‰, Î»Î±Ï†á½»ÏƒÏƒÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ ï¼ˆHom. Il. 18.583ï¼‰. These Curtius refers to â€œthe want of proper linguistic instinct on the part of some late rhapsodist. â€ ï¼ˆbï¼‰ Attic 2nd pers. in â€Ï„Î·Î½ instead of â€Ï„Î¿Î½. Our Îµá¼°Ï‡á½³Ï„Î·Î½ here is the only instance proved by metre: but 8 others are established. Against these fall to be set at least 13 Attic instances of the normal â€Ï„Î¿Î½. Curtius regards the 2nd pers. in â€Ï„Î·Î½ as due to a false analogy. In the third person dual â€Ï„Î·Î½ was distinctive of the secondary tenses. Attic speech sometimes extended this distinction to the second person also. ï¼ˆCurt. Verb 1.80, Eng. tr. 53.ï¼‰ Cp n. on Soph. OC 1378 ff.

Î¿á½— ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼á¾· Î¶á¿†Î½, Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… Î´á½² Î»á¿´Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚

Line 1513

I preferÎ¿á½— ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼á¾· Î¶á¿†Î½, Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… Îº.Ï„.Î». to Î¿á½— ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼€Îµá½¶ Î¶á¿†Î½, Î²á½·Î¿Ï… Îº.Ï„.Î». on these grounds. 1. Ï„Î¿á¿¦ before Î²á½·Î¿Ï…, though not required, is commended, by Greek idiom; it also gives a decidedly better rhythm; and it is not likely to have crept into the text, since the occurrence of á¼€Îµá½· with the Î± long was not so uncommon that it should have suggested the need of supplementing the metre by Ï„Î¿á¿¦: but, apart from metrical motive, there was no other for intruding the article. 2. Î¿á½— ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¹Ï‚, without any verb, though a possible phrase, is a harsh one. 3. From ÎµÎ±Î¹ to Î±ÎµÎ¹ would be an easy transition. AndÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼á¾· is quite a natural expression: cp. Eur. IA 858 Î´Î¿á¿¦Î»Î¿Ï‚Â· Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼Î²Ïá½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿·Î´â€™Â· á¼¡ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î· Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½Îº á¼á¾·. The foreboding of Oedipus is that his daughters must become homeless exiles ï¼ˆ1506ï¼‰ unless Creon shelters them at Thebes. â€œTo live where occasion allowsâ€ means in his inner thought, â€œto live at Thebes, if that may beâ€”if not, in the least unhappy exile that the gods may grant you. â€ The monosyllabic á¼”Î± ï¼ˆ1451, Soph. Meineke's conjecture, á¾–, gives a more prosaic phrase, and is too far from the á¼€Îµá½· of the MSS.

á¼ƒ Î¼á½´ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶ In Soph. OC 765 ff.ï¼‰ Creon is represented as opposing a distinct refusal to this prayer of Oedipus. Line 1529

The use of á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± is peculiar. I take the exact sense to be: â€”â€œfixing one's eye on the final day ï¼ˆas on a point towards which one is movingï¼‰, that one should see it,â€ i.e. â€œuntil one shall have had experience of it.â€ Thus á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ is used in a sense closely akin to its common sense of â€œattentively consideringâ€ a thing: and the whole phrase is virtually equivalent to, â€œwaiting meditatively to see the final day.â€ For the added infin., cp. Thuc. 3.2 Î½Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï€Î¿á½·Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼Ï€á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏƒÎ¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹, ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½…ÏƒÎ± á¼Îº Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï… á¼”Î´ÎµÎ¹ á¼€Ï†Î¹Îºá½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. Cp. Plin. NH 7.132 alius de alio iudicat dies, et tamen supremus de omnibus, ideoque nullis credendum est. Hartung proposed to replace á¼°Î´Îµá¿–Î½ by Î³Îµ Î´Îµá¿– ï¼ˆwhere Î³Îµ would be intolerableï¼‰; Stanley by á¼”Î´ÎµÎ¹, Seyffert by Î´á½³Î¿Î½, and Nauck by Ï‡ÏÎµá½½Î½. Kennedy, keeping á¼°Î´Îµá¿–Î½, changes á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î·Î½ into á¼„Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î½Î¿Î½. But the infin. á½€Î»Î²á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ as a â€œsententiousâ€ imperative ï¼ˆsee on 462ï¼‰ is appropriate in this Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î·. The accus. ï¼ˆÎ¸Î½Î·Ï„á½¸Î½ á½„Î½Ï„â€™, á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±ï¼‰ stands with the infin. when, as here, the infin. represents an imperat. of the third person; cp. Hom. Il. 3.284 Îµá¼° Î´á½³ Îºâ€™ á¼ˆÎ»á½³Î¾Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Î½ ÎºÏ„Îµá½·Î½á¿ƒ Î¾Î±Î½Î¸á½¸Ï‚ ÎœÎµÎ½á½³Î»Î±Î¿Ï‚, | Î¤Ïá¿¶Î±Ï‚ á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î¸â€™ á¼™Î»á½³Î½Î·Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÏ„á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´Î¿á¿¦Î½Î±Î¹, with Leaf's note: and Madvig Gr. sect. 546. When the infin. = an imperat. of the second pers., the case is regularly the nom. ï¼ˆHom. Od. 11.441ï¼‰, rarely the acc. ï¼ˆHes. WD 389ï¼‰. The view that á½€Î»Î²á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ depends on á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ requires a shorter pause at á¼Î»á½µÎ»Ï…Î¸ÎµÎ½, and thus weakens the effect of v. 1527. Î¼Î·Î´á½³Î½â€™ á½€Î»Î²á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½. Eur. Andr. 100 ff. partly reproduces the language of this passage: Ï‡Ïá½´ Î´â€™ Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½â€™ á½„Î»Î²Î¹Î¿Î½ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½, | Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á¼‚Î½ Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„Î±á½·Î±Î½ á¼´Î´á¿ƒÏ‚ | á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏá½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î½ á¼¥Î¾ÎµÎ¹ Îºá½±Ï„Ï‰. He has the thought also in Eur. Tro. 510, Eur. Her. 866, Eur. IA 161, as Soph. in Soph. Tr. 1 and fr. 588. The maxim, â€œCall no man happy before death,â€ first appears in Greek literature as a set Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î· in Aesch. Ag. 928 á½€Î»Î²á½·ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î´á½² Ï‡Ïá½´ | Î²á½·Î¿Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½µÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Î½ Îµá½ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿– Ï†á½·Î»á¿ƒ: but Aristotle recognises the popular tradition which ascribed it to Solon. In Hdt. 1.32 Solon says that a man may be called Îµá½Ï„Ï…Ï‡á½µÏ‚ in life, but á½„Î»Î²Î¹Î¿Ï‚ only after a life exempt from reverse. Cp. Iuv. 10.274 ff. Et Croesum, quem vox iusti facunda Solonis Respicere ad longae iussit spatia ultima vitae, where Mayor refers to the proverbs Î›Ï…Î´á½¸Ï‚ ï¼ˆCroesusï¼‰ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î¸Î½á½µÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÎ¿Ï†á½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½µÏ, and Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á½…ÏÎ± Î²á½·Î¿Ï… ï¼ˆParmoemiogr. 11. 187, I. 315 n.ï¼‰, and to notices of the saying in Cic. ï¼ˆDe Fin. 2.87, 3.76ï¼‰, Diog. Laert. ï¼ˆDiog. Laert. 1.50 Ï„á½± Î¸ÏÏ…Î»Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î±ï¼‰, Ovid ï¼ˆOvid Met. 3.135ï¼‰, Seneca ï¼ˆDe Tranq. An. 11.12ï¼‰, Josephus ï¼ˆBell. Iud. 1.5.11=29.3ï¼‰, Arrian ï¼ˆ7 sect. 16.7ï¼‰, Lucian ï¼ˆCharon 10ï¼‰: cp. Ecclus. 11. 28. Does Solon mean, Aristotle asks, ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ that a man is happy when he is dead? Or ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰ that, after death, he may be said to have been happy? If ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰, Arist. declines to allow that the dead are positively happy; and popular opinion, he says, denies that they are always negatively so, i.e. free from unhapppiness. If ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰, then is it not absurd that at the time when he ishappy we are not to call him so? The fallacy, he concludes, consists in treating â€œhappinessâ€ as dependant on bright fortunes: Î¿á½ Î³á½±Ï á¼Î½ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î±Î¹Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Îµá½– á¼¢ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ á¼€Î»Î»á½° Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ´Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ á½ á¼€Î½Î¸ÏÏ‰Ï€Î¿Ï‚ Î²á½·Î¿Ï‚, ÎºÎ±Î¸á½±Ï€ÎµÏ Îµá¼´Ï€Î±Î¼ÎµÎ½, Îºá½»ÏÎ¹Î±Î¹ Î´â€™ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¶Î½ Î±á¼± ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼€ÏÎµÏ„á½´Î½ á¼Î½á½³ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Îµá½Î´Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½Î¹Î±Ï‚, Î±á¼± Î´â€™ á¼Î½Î±Î½Ï„á½·Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼Î½Î±Î½Ï„á½·Î¿Ï…. ï¼ˆAristot.
